This review is for the Earthbath Hot Spot & Itch Relief Spray (Amazon lumps all the varieties of sprays together):

Did ABSOLUTELY NOTHING! for my dog's itchy paws.  My dog has been licking her paws over and over for years, and we have done dietary elimination trials, organic raw food, allergy shots for desensitization to inhalant allergens, fish oil, coconut oil, homeopathy, allergy meds with antihistamines, allergy meds with steroids, followed Dr. Plechner's low dose cortisol regimen (which worked, but she develops iatrogenic Cushing's even on low dose steroids--yikes); we've done it all.  We don't use chemicals in our house or yard.  So now I am looking for something to give her relief.  A steroid spray works but the one we have smells terrible (who picked that fragrance!) and I wanted something natural to try.

The sprayer is hard to depress--I have to use the heel of my hand to get a sptitz; it smells like tea tree oil and the smell does not persist, but my dog just licks it off her paws and then resumes her licking until her parts of her paws get raw and bleed.
Stopped working after only 3 weeks

Makes wounds bleed more; doesn't help pain whatsoever; smells like minty toothpaste; and a big waste of packaging.

Because of the good reviews and the bottle saying it's for minor wounds, I tried this on my toy poodle who had a tiny bit of razor burn in a sensitive area after returning from the groomers. She immediately started to bleed and tried to lick at it. The bottle says licking is okay, but it smells exactly like my dog's toothpaste, so it really just encourages licking, which defeats the whole purpose of putting it on in the first place.

Because the bottle says it's also safe for humans, I tried it on myself where I accidentally knicked my finger while prepping food the previous day since it was still sore. Not only did it start bleeding again, but it did absolutely nothing for the pain and just made a big oily mess I had to wipe off around the cut.

The item comes in a tiny burlap sack that serves absolutely no useful purpose whatever, and that comes in a bigger decorative cardboard box with padding (that's covered with labels so it's not even reusable), which is a huge waste of materials and serves no purpose either.

They seem like a nice company, and this might legitimately work on sore muscles--i have no idea. But if you're looking for a wound spray that's functional instead of focusing on cute packaging, this isn't it.

I live where the water is so soft there's almost no minerals in it at all. Maintaining a Ph of 7.0 was difficult but possible, but my snails had the white pitting and my guppy had fin rot that he contracted during the time when I was totally new to fish keeping and didn't understand how important it is to snails and guppies to keep the Ph at or above 7.0.

I had finally got the situation under control. My guppy's fins were regenerating and my snails had new shell growth that was healthy.

Then I made the grave mistake of trying this product. Aloe vera? So what. Looked like a stupid gimmick. Since when do fish need aloe vera? Do we need to pull them out of the tank and rub moisturizing cream on them too? How about some Lubriderm?

Anyway, shortly after switching to this product my Ph crashed to 6.0. My guppy's fins started rotting and got worse than ever, and the healthy growth on my snails that survived me climbing the learning curve last Summer now have white calcified shell damage. I don't even recognize the two I named just a few months ago!

I was doing emergency water changes morning and evening just to keep the Ph at about 6.4. (My tap water is totally soft, but comes out of the tap at PH of about 7.2). My hands got raw and cracked because I was washing my hands so much after working with the tank so much.

I asked myself what had changed when this started, and the only thing I came up with was switching to this aloe vera stress coat. Then I looked up aloe vera juice on the Internet and found it has a Ph of 3.5 to 5.0 depending on where I looked. Wow, I thought, maybe putting something with Ph that low in the tank could throw the whole Ph down quite a bit.

I bought some Tetra brand stress coat and did a few more water changes (some cracks in hands bleeding now, maybe MY hands could use some aloe vera!!) and soon the Ph climbed back up to 6.8.

I did two emergency salt dips for the guppy, whose fin rot had begun on his body too. It looks like the rot has been halted. The damage has been done to my snails. Maybe once I get this under control I'll have time to just stare at the tank a while and figure out who is who again through all the shell damage.

So, thanks API for putting my fish and snails through hell. Brilliant idea mixing a super low Ph substance in with water conditioner. Did you test this thoroughly before you put it into production? Anyway, I could rant further but I think it's time to rub some Vaseline moisture lotion on my cloud fish. They really need to chill out.
summary: Recommend trying the small size first.  I think this stuff almost killed my tank.

reviewText:
This is too small for a betta fish. I know it seems counterintuitive but most pet stores and suppliers are misinformed about bettas. Learn about betta fish and their care from breeders and enthusiasts (like the Nippy Fish site), NOT sellers. To dispel some common myths about bettas:

- They do not live in small dirty puddles in the wild. The recommended tank size is 5+ gallons. They need at LEAST 1 gallon, and 2.5 gallons and up is much better.
- They shouldn't be with or near other bettas unless breeding.
- They are carnivores and need carnivore fish food. They do not eat plants, and they shouldn't eat dried pellets, flakes or freeze-dried food, which bind them up.
- They need heated water (75-80).
- They need a clean tank just like every other fish.
- A single betta with the correct supplies for living by itself will cost about $100. Or it can live in a larger aquarium with certain types of other fish.

Hope that helps!

I am on the board of an animal shelter, and have 23 cats of my own.  We were directed to Wellness as an excellent no-grain food.  We buy the largest sized cans, and we spend almost $800 per month on this food.  The cats used to love all of the flavors we bought (Turkey, Chx, Chx and Beef, Turkey and Salmon) and suddenly NONE of them will eat ANY of them!  I can only surmise that something has happened to the recipe, or the quality of the ingredients.  It makes no sense.  More bizarre, we feed the outdoor (feral) cats the food and many of them won't touch it, either.  The hunt is on to find the next "great food"...
summary: The recipe or ingredient quality has changed (?)

reviewText:
I've had this door installed for about a week. My dog is already doggie door trained. She's a pretty intelligent client. However, even an intelligent dog and an adult human (that has read over and over the instruction manual) can have a hard time figuring out the automatic setting on this door. And I finally figured out why we were having such difficultly- the door only works when it wants to. The sensor isn't nearly powerful enough (on any range setting). My dog is pretty low to the ground and the key only seems to work when I point it directly at the door. Needless to say, I haven't quite trained my dog to turn and position the key just right in relation to the door- lacking thumbs and all, it would be kind of difficult for her.

Also when it does register, the door only stays unlocked for a few seconds before it locks again and resets. So if you're dog doesn't make it out of the door in time, they have to stand there for 10 seconds until the door registers the key again. I've tried to explain this to my dog, but I don't think she gets it. She just scratches on the door and when it doesn't open, pisses on the carpet.

If your dog does manage to point the key at the right angle and moves fast enough to get out of the door before it closes- the door can still get stuck in the open position. If the door is open when it attempts to lock it just freezes where ever it happens to be. Letting my cats out and defeating the purpose of having an automatic dog door in the first place. If I didn't care what animals got in or out of my house I would have bought a cheap flappy door or cut a random hole in the wall for free.

In my opinion, PetSafe has to step it up before anyone else bothers to install this door. Just house train your dog, pay a pet sitter, take your dog to work with you, or just don`t get a dog at all. All of these options are better than buying this door.

PetSafe: Just because your's is the only product on the market doesn't give you the right to suck.
summary: The rating of this door gets lower and lower everyday

I have a dog, and sometimes I just don't have enough time to shampoo the carpets once a month, so I as hoping that this product would help to cover the longer stretches between shampoos. After 2 uses I would definitely not recommend this product. Here's the highlights from my experience with it:

Smell:
While this stuff does alter the scent, it is not a very pleasant one, but tolerable, I wouldn't want my house smelling like it regularly, though.

Packaging:
The packaging is cardboard spiraled into a cylinder, imagine those ready to bake cinnamon roll packages. Upon two uses the center of the container feels like it is collapsing. I cannot imagine the container making it through the length of time it would take to use all the product.

Residue:
I have off white carpets. This stuff left white residue all over the carpets, it makes my carpet look dirtier than it did initially. I literally bought a new vacuum because if it. I had wanted a new vacuum for awhile, and that the residue did not come up made me think that it was time. Purchased a new vacuum with over 1,000 reviews and a 4.5 star rating, and the residue still remained. I wish I had thought to read the reviews because I now see that other people have had the same issue.

Conclusion:
Bad packaging, subpar scent, white residue all over your carpet. This stuff is a fail. I am actually worse off having used it!
summary: I am actually worse off having used it! Residue all over my carpet!

reviewText: I bought several flea combs at once to find a good one since I couldn't tell from pictures what the teeth spacing was like or the quality of the combs. My dog had a thick double coat and I was concerned about being able to comb through to get fleas since combing him would result in a comb full of the undercoat hairs no matter how much he was brushed prior. This is a review of Safari Flea Comb for Dogs with wood handle. This flea comb seems to have a bigger space between the teeth, and didn't remove fleas as easily as other combs. Also it rusted fast within the first week of use. I used the comb along with bathing of my dog since with wet fur it was easier to spot the red-brown fleas or Dog Flea ( Ctenocephalides canis ) that are more flat with fat rears. Dog fleas' strategy was to grip the fur and stay on, making me have to comb several times on the flea to try to dislodge it, Sometimes the flea was very good and scraping and combing the flea would take awhile to get it loose. Also, this comb isn't very useful for Cat fleas (Ctenocephalides felis) since those cat fleas have smaller black bodies that are narrow and easily crawl out of the teeth to hop away if I didn't thrust my comb into soapy water fast enough, and yes I tried to get them in the soap water asap, into a separate bowl. Fleas are sneaky and like to crawl up the dog to air if the dog is sitting in water, soap water also makes it harder for the black colored Cat Flea to use its wings for a big hop away escape. Bottom line is this comb was a big disappointment and waste of money. The best comb that I wish I had and knew about years ago was an all metal flea comb B0002ASFZU Pet Comb for Fleas

reviewText:
Received it on a Thursday, put it on our puppy -- by the following Monday morning, I yanked it off. Can't rate if it works for teas and ticks, but it repels humans just fine ... my fingers and hands began to blister, itch and then felt like they were on fire. It began gradually over the weekend until I put two-and-two together, and realized I was having a major reaction to the collar. Wasn't going to take the chance that the puppy would be affected to.

The active ingredient in the collar is imidacloprid and flumethrin, one (or both) of which is what I must be reacting to ... the only solution is to avoid my dog ... like that's ever going to happen. Blisters so bad that some are opening up, and I'm having to cover the open sores with band-aids.

Don't buy ... expensive lesson to learn. Our first dog used Advantix, and we'll go back to that again.
summary: Horrible chemical reaction ... not to the dog, but to human

reviewText: The puppy bumber did not work for what I needed it too.

I buy a lot of products on Amazon and WOULD have purchased these here, BUT I got a free sample from my vet and will NEVER buy these!!!!

I told the girl at my vets reception desk that my dog could only tolerate a grain free diet (gets rashes and upset tummy from a few ingredients) The girl looked at the packet but didn't hand it to me, and said that these were vegetable based and would be fine. I wanted to insist that I read it myself and didn't. I am usually very thorough about such things. My bad! My dog eats a lot of fruit and vegetables along with her excellent diet of Primal and Orijen and Arcana dog food (all of which have vegetable and fruit content - but no grains)  so I figured plant fiber shouldn't be a problem.

A few hours after I gave her the chew she started having loose stools.
Then all night long she kept waking me up to go outside.
I get up this morning and she has leaked all over the carpet in multiple places (she looked so sad about that, poor thing) Because its so watery and the treats are dark green, it has stained my carpet permanently and I have professional strength stain remover)
24 hours later she is still going (liquid), and the skin around her bottom and under her tail is red and sore.
I called the vet and reported it and got the name of the brand and looked up the ingredients.

Ingredients
Corn Starch, Glycerin, Soy Bean Protein, Rice Flour, Palatable Agent (Sacharomyces cerevisiae), Sorbitol, Corn Cob, Water, Potassium Sorbate. Made in Vietnam.
I was not surprised but was disappointed to see this list.

NOTE THAT THERE ARE NO VEGETABLES IN THIS CHEW! Dried corn is a grain, not a vegetable.
On the CET site "Veggie-based chews ideal for daily use in a home dental care regimen
Clean your dog's teeth and freshen his breath - in one easy step! VeggieDent is a delicious, veggie-based chew..."
The manufacturers claim that these are veggie based chews are misleading. These are GRAIN CHEWS!
Also, why are they dark green? There is no green plant matter in them!

Now, the ingredients: (please note that I did a quick search on each ingredient. Many other references other than the ones provided are available. You may wish to cross check this information with other sources. I am not a vet. Just a concerned puppy mother)

Corn and corn cobs:
Corn is not good for any dog as it is very high on the glycaemic index. the more finely the corn is ground, the more if affects blood sugar. It is also highly indigestable and many dogs have allergic reactions and digestion problems with it.  Corn is added to so many dog foods because it is a cheap filler as it is an industrial biproduct from the human food industry which equals more $$$ for dog food manufacturers.

Soy Bean Protein:
"Soy has been linked to gas and deadly bloat in dogs. It is high in purines and is therefore a completely inappropriate protein source for urate-forming dogs. It is also high in silicates and promotes the formation of silica stones. The carbohydrate action of soy can cause a rise in blood sugar in many cats. Soy is also linked to thyroid damage.....The ingestion of soybean products is also linked to seizures in both dogs and cats.
I hope I've given you a more complete understanding of why avoiding pet foods containing soy products is best for your favorite four-legged companion. In my opinion, the potential risks associated with feeding soy are simply unacceptable  especially when you consider your carnivorous cat or dog prefers and receives a much higher level of nutrition from animal protein sources. "  Dr Karen Becker. Mercola.

Sorbitol:
"Sugar or sweetener is an absolutely unnecessary ingredient in pet foods, added to make the product more attractive. Continuous intake can promote hypoglycemia, obesity, nervousness, cataracts, tooth decay, arthritis and allergies. Pets also get addicted to foods that contain sugars, so it can be a tough piece of work to make them eat something healthier." The Dog Food Project

Rice Flour:
Also a very high glycaemic food.

Saccharomyces cerevisiae
This is a yeast. The media upon which it was grown has not been identified but according to the Dog Food Project and many other sources it is a potential allergen dor some dogs.

Potassium Sorbate:
"Potassium sorbate is considered safe for both dogs and cats at a maximum content of 5 000 mg/kg semi-moist complete feed, based on the limited data available in the public literature. Potassium sorbate is a skin and eye irritant and a potential irritant of the respiratory tract." European Food Safety Authority

The manufacturer of these chews is cutting corners and profit is thier first priority. They are not in the business of manufacturing healthy chews. I see that there are many positive reviews here for them. And if your dog didn't react then that is great. My dog loved the taste! BUT, keep in mind the very high glycaemic index of these chews if you are concerned about your dogs weight or blood sugar , and if your dog does get rashes or an upset tummy after eating these then it will be the corn and/or the sorbitol and/or the soy.
Hope this helps someone. Now I have to go get something to soothe and heal her poor little scalded butt and tail.

PS. If anyone is looking for a good dog chew, I use Zukes Z-Bones (made in the US)  carrot, apple, berry chews occasionally as a very special treat (potato is very high glycaemic so I give these rarely)
CARROT: Potato Flour, Peas, Tapioca, Vegetable Glycerine, Pea Protein, Carrots, Pumpkin, Lecithin, Natural Flavor, Caramel, Betacarotene, Parsley, Citric Acid, Zinc Propionate, Alfalfa, Rosemary, Turmeric, Fennel
BERRY:Potato Flour, Peas, Tapioca, Vegetable Glycerine, Pea Protein, Cherries, Cranberries, Lecithin, Natural Flavor, Beet Powder, Citric Acid, Zinc Propionate, Alfalfa, Parsley, Rosemary, Turmeric, Fennel
APPLE:Potato Flour, Vegetable Glycerine, Peas, Tapioca, Pea Protein, Apples, Spinach, Lecithin, Natural Flavor, Parsley, Rosemary, Citric Acid, Zinc Propionate, Turmeric, Alfalfa, Fennel

Update - we received it, yeah!

They also tell you that during the initial phase, they tell you not use typical clay lumping litter.  My cats have grown up using this so it will be curious to see if they take to it.

Update 9/14
Lesson:  Do not buy this from the Botanical (the distributor)!
We found out one of the shelves is broken so I first tried to go through the manufacturer - they told me to go through the distributor.  The distributor then told me that if it was damaged in shipment, we should have refused it from UPS.  Considering I was not there, that was a little hard to do.  Either way, I asked that I did not want to disrupt training so could I get another one - they told me that I would have to pay for that one.  Unbelievable!

Update 10/22

The seat is now sitting outside in the rain waiting for the next garbage pickup- the slats would not stay in place and had a tendency to collapse when our heavier cat got on the seat when we had it on the floor.  Poor, poor product - not worth $89 that's for sure.

We found a tiny puppy on the side of the road that someone had dumped. The next day I went to the pet store to get him some essential items until we decided what to do with him. One of the bones I bought looked very similar to these and he LOVED it. So, when I saw these on Amazon I figured he'd be just as crazy about them. Not so. I would offer him one and he'd turn his head in disgust. I tried again a couple of days later and he had the same reaction. I ended up giving them to a coworker who said his dogs would eat anything. I'm sure that most dogs would love them - what's not to love? It's turkey and sweet potato. That said, I also tried giving our puppy a peanut butter stuffed Kong and he looked at me like I was crazy. I've NEVER known a dog that didn't like peanut butter. So... maybe our little guy is just really picky.

reviewText: I rarely give items one star, but these caps are just awful. I ordered them for my two average sized cats, followed the sizing chart and waited excitedly for their arrival. Unfortunately, when these arrived, I noticed that they are far thicker than the previous brands we have ordered. I decided to test it out on one of my cats nails without the glue, and as I suspected, had I applied these, my cat would not have been able to comfortably retract his nails. This can lead to an infection and horrible discomfort for the cats, so we tossed these and ordered a different pair, which although a bit more expensive, was well worth the extra money to keep my cat comfortable and safe.
summary: Too thick - would work for dogs not cats.

reviewText:
I know that you are purchasing this because you love your pet; and because you love your pet you want to do what's best for them. Homeopathic/natural medicines are usually better for you and thus for your pets, right? Sometimes... But just because something is safe for people to imbibe doesn't mean that it is safe for animals to... Garlic is one of those things...

Ok, let me admit that I haven't, and won't be purchasing something like this for animal that I don't want to kill, so I haven't tried this product...

So, where do I get off giving this a one star review? LOTS AND LOTS of veterinary knowledge and research. Go ahead and do a Google search on "garlic dog poison" or "garlic cat poison". If you do you will see that garlic is only slightly less bad for dogs and cats than antifreeze is. YES, you read that correctly, ANTIFREEZE! It causes the similar symptoms, too; a slow buildup that doesn't flush out of the system, but slowly causes blood failure (in amounts this small, or in larger amounts your pet could be dead today).

In checking the ingredients, yes, this does have garlic in it (rather than just a flavoring agent that encourages animals to eat things that are poisonous to them). Probably not in levels that will kill your pet in the first few months, but in a year, or two, or maybe three?

---------------------------
I don't know if Amazon will let me post links, as they often don't, but...

Especially read the last paragraph, on the first page of this comprehensive article:
http://veterinarymedicine.dvm360.com/toxicology-brief-allium-species-poisoning-dogs-and-cats?rel=canonical

For a super brief, simple overview and a list of common symptoms, read this article:
http://www.petpoisonhelpline.com/poison/garlic/
summary: Did you know that garlic is POISONOUS to dogs and cats?!!!

This is not the same product as was previously sold with an almost identical name.  The "good" packaging has a silhouette of a dog.  The "bad" packaging, pictured here, has a photo of a dog in the water.  Included in the "good" product description is the statement "Including many strains is important because the gut environment is a diverse one" -- and yet in the new, "bad" product they have eliminated all but one strain!  AND raised the price!!!  With this change in formula and with the deceptive packaging, I have lost ALL FAITH in Vetri-Science, a company whose products I have been buying for at least 4 years.  Count me out!!!

The description of the "good" product lists the ingredients:  Characterized by the inclusion of nine strains of probiotics, Vetri Probiotic Everyday Chews offer a wide spectrum of support. This chew contains 286 million CFU/gram of beneficial bacteria, including Bacillus subtilis, Bacillus coagulans, Lactobacillus acidophilus, Bifidobacterium thermophilum, Bifidobacterium longum, Lactobacillus fermentum, Lactobacillus casei, Bifidobacterium bifidum, and Enterococcus faecium. Including many strains is important because the gut environment is a diverse one.
summary: Buyer Beware!!! Product has changed for the worse!

I have been feeding my two 1.5 year old cats this product for the last year or so. Initially, I had no problems with it because my girls loved the flavor and I thought it was helping with one of my cats sensitive digestive system. A few weeks ago, she started having problems again without any change in her diet, so I did an online search on whether Natural Balance changed its formula. I couldn't find anything on that but I did find a bunch of disturbing images of stones and pebbles in their products that customers found as well as reviews of pet owners who reported a decline in their cats' health due to this product. I was concerned but my vet told me he wasn't aware of any issues with Natural Balance. Then today I found 2 pieces of rocks in my cats' canned food (see image). What is disturbing is that I've seen it before in their food but I thought it was supposed to be part of it and didn't inspect it further. I wish I had researched this product more extensively prior to placing my cats on this diet. I will no longer buy products from Natural Balance and I will likely have my vet runs tests on my cats to make sure this didn't cause permanent damage to them.

I recently started up a 75g reef tank, still in the cycling process. I purchased this because 1. its fairly inexpensive for what it is 2. Was curious to see if it actually worked, given the mixed reviews here on Amazon 3. I was hoping it would limit the amount of testing I would have to do initially. I really wanted to like this product but it failed miserably. After initiating my fish less cycle, and raising my ammonia to 5ppm, I opened the product and read the instructions carefully before attaching it onto the inside of the tank. With readings well into the toxic range from my reliable test kit, my Ammonia alert steadily read 0 or "safe" for 3 days before I eventually tossed it, wanted to give it the benefit of the doubt. Not once did it go above yellow, not once. I can not recommend this product to anyone, especially if you intend to use this as your primary testing method ; ammonia creates an excruciating death for your fish if not properly remedied. Play it safe and test the good ole fashioned way. I still use several Seachem products that are great in my opinion and this product doesn't change that.
summary: I'm glad I didn't test this product with my fish's lives

reviewText:
Hairballs Out Of Control should be the new name of the cat food after Hill's changed the formula. My cat has been on Hill's Hairball Control Dry Cat Food for close to 5 years. While on the old formula she produced a hairball once every three months. She was originally put on the formula after she regularly had poop sticking to her after going to the bathroom. The hairball control cat food cleared that up. However, since Hill's recently changed the formula for their hairball control dry cat food my cat has thrown up hairballs at least once a week creating messes everywhere. My cat has been on the new formula for about 3 months now. Since her throwing up hairballs constantly isn't getting any better I will be transitioning her to new food.

I realize a few others have noted the same problem with the new formula. Hopefully if enough of us voice our complaint  Hill's will change the formula back or at least resolve the issue with the new formula causing cats to throw up hairballs on a weekly basis (which is exactly what the hairball control cat food is suppose to prevent).

UPDATE 12/3/13:
Since the original review I transitioned my cat to Royal Canin Intense Hairball 34 Formula. She has been on Royal Canin solely for about 6 weeks now. After switching to Royal Canin my cat has completely stopped coughing up hairballs. If your cat has hairball problems with Hill's like my cat did I highly recommend trying Royal Canin Intense Hairball 34 Formula.
summary: UPDATE: Hairballs Out Of Control With New Formula

When the measurements showed that I needed a size 2, 3, and 4 for my German Shepherds I thought something must be wrong so I called the Baskerville company directly for assistance.  They assured me that those would be the correct sizes for my dogs.  When they arrived I found that they are ALL too small.  Even the size 4 doesn't fit the dog that the size 2 was supposed to fit.  So even the customer service reps at the manufacturer can't get the sizing right.

For an item that relies on proper fit for successful use, I find this misinformation unacceptable.  I had seen reviews here before I ordered regarding the problems with sizing, which is why I called the company prior to ordering.  I sent an email to the company explaining the problem after I received the muzzles and also telling them this really makes it difficult for me as I do rescue work and buying the muzzles was a financial strain for me with all the other expenses that come with rescue, and now I have muzzles that won't work at all because I followed their recommendations.  They never bothered to respond.  Obviously they do not care about their customers or about getting something as basic as the sizing correct.

I did not return the muzzles as I may have smaller rescues in here at some point that can use them.  I am going to order more muzzles for the Shepherds but they will be another brand since Baskerville doesn't seem to want to help their customers at all.
summary: Sizing is so far off and company can't help

reviewText:
My 12-14 year old Akbash has been pacing and panting almost all night for a few months. Very definite signs of "sundowning". It's been heart breaking to watch him get so confused. Both of us have been getting about 3 hours of sleep on any given night.
I decided to try Senilife after reading great reviews and doing lots of research. Unfortunately he has shown no improvement in 30 days of consistent usage. Maybe that could change if given longer, but I didn't want to potentially waste another $40, or spend another month with no sleep. I ordered Neutricks and I will give an update if anything changes!
Update:
Have been giving him Neutricks for about a month, and he is sleeping better, with the occasional bad night. I will also be adding Cholodin soon.

I read some of the reviews on different products to help the smell from cat litter boxes and I want to say to you guys, be careful and read the warning labels, some of those products shouldn't be in a cat litter box. You can read the labels online before you buy them, just look for the ingredients and any warning labels. I found some that are meant for fish water and has no business in a cat litter box. reviewText:
Purchased for our primary car, which is a 2010 Kia Soul. Our 20 lb. eight-month-old corgi has figured out how to get either over the center barrier or under the hammock, which means him getting up front and disrupting our driving. We are tired of the front of our car being covered in dog hair, and when I drive alone, he wants to sit right in my lap. I have tried every different combination of tighter and looser clasps, as well as different positioning of the slips that go into the back seat. It cannot simultaneously be super taught up front and in back, so he'll get up front one way or another.

Two stars because the pockets are a nice touch that I haven't seen on many other hammock seat covers and it seems to have quality waterproofing. Unfortunately, that doesn't do us much good when our wet dog can still get under the cover to be on the seat cushion anyway. This may work for those with bigger dogs and bigger cars. For those with smaller cars, and smaller dogs (especially smart ones) -- I would recommend something else.
summary: Did Not Work For My Kia Soul and Corgi Puppy

reviewText:
I bought two of these, used for a month before we got a new dog; and now with the dog (which was original intent). Both my husband and I have Honda Pilots ('09 & '16).
Pros:
Easy to attach to seat. The two handles are clever--just push 'em into seat & cover stays in place.
Looks great.
Good price.
To protect your backseat from daily chores/activities (i.e. throwing in golf bags, groceries, spills, kids!) I think it'd be great.

Cons:
Ok, it may be my new pooch, but how the heck does one 'de-fur' this cover? I've tried washing, just fluffing in dryer, shaking it out, even vacuuming. I have a short hair, lab/boxer mix and it's like trying to get pine needles picked up after Christmas. I bought the black which REALLY shows up the fur; bought the beige for my husband's Honda Pilot, and at least fur (dog is tan) blends in well.

Thoughts:
I plan to put velcro on the two slits that allow one to reach the seatbelt buckles, and close off openings so fur doesn't go through.
With the protective backing, stays on my leather seat reasonably well; but stays in place much better on my husband's cloth seat.
Dog likes 'em! Now just wish he could clean up after himself!
summary: Great for uses other than dog

reviewText: This didn't work out for my pup. Rather than comforting him, he seemed to want to attack it, whether the heartbeat module was turned on or turned off. He was able to ingest a lot of the high pile hair , and then of course he threw it up. A few days after having it, I found one of the ears on the floor. So he was able to chew it off quite easily.

I didn't see any noticeable difference when using this on my dog's teeth.  My dog wasn't too thrilled with me putting it on his teeth either, although he didn't seem to mind the taste, and it does have a pleasant smell.  I ended up buying a tooth scraper, which works much better--although the dog is not too thrilled with me doing that either, but at least it works!
summary: Never saw any difference in my dog's teeth.

reviewText: I have purchased two of these in the past 4-5 months and each one lasted about a month. After that time, the edging, or binding around the actual cloth of the harness comes unstitched. At that point, the rest of the material begins to more or less disintegrate in a few days. Very poor workmanship.
It was considerably smaller than it should have been. Did not accommodate a 25 lb. dog at all.

If you decide to purchase this for your loved dog, you won't question the quality of the ingredients. It's good stuff. That said, when this was slowly introduced, bit by more bit, to my very sensitive and selective GSD, he liked it. But it took him the longest-ever time for his system to adjust. He had diarrhea throughout and when he finally figured out towards the bag's finish (yes, we took this very slowly), that it was this ZiwiPeak food making his tummy hurt and spew painful bathroom time, he began to avoid eating it. Quite a few reviewers mention that this was also for the sensitive and finicky, but sadly for my poor guy, it wasn't so.

This food is very dry and handles well. It looks like small square-cut flattened jerky. In fact, they're so small and flat that my big dog consistently struggled to eat all the ones that were stuck to the bottom of his food bowl. Given how pricey this food is, it seemed wasteful, the amount that my dog couldn't bite or lick up. So each and every time I had to scrape up the stuck saliva-ridden, very thin jerky squares he couldn't manage to get into his mouth, which he'd then finally get to finish. It was added effort for each meal to have to do. If they could offer this in a bigger, thicker cut for bigger dogs' mouths, it could be ideal for those without sensitivity issues.

This came in a resealable bag, which was nice. This would have been perfect for traveling, if only it hadn't disrupted his bowels. Perhaps it was just a simple case of him needing more time to adjust to, for instance, the "green-lipped mussel" ingredient? Unfortunately, we shall never know...

(MADE IN NEW ZEALAND)
summary: Picky and Sensitive Shepherd Was Not a Fan

reviewText: I found out about these litterboxes by going into a pet store for cat supplies when I adopted my cat back in 2005. I liked the idea that I no longer would have to worry about having to scoop out cat waste or have a strong cat waste smell in my home.  I bought the LM920 which I found to have a quiet and decent motor. Unfortunately, it only lasted about three years.  Then I bought the LM900 as the LM920 was no longer made even though it is superior to the LM900 and quieter.  The first LM900 I bought lasted about a year and half, and I found the motor noisy and not very sturdy.  The second LM900 lasted about a year.  I bought the third LM900 and it only lasted two days before the rake stopped in the dumping into the receptacle mode and wouldn't move anymore.  I had to unscrew the rake so I could empty the receptacle which was full of lovely cat waste, dump the current amount of cat litter and return it to Amazon so I could get a replacement.  The replacement one broke also with the rake in the upright position so again, I had to unscrew the rake to get to the almost full receptacle to dump it out. Don't bother buying the Littermaid LM900 model as it is obviously doesn't last.  I went and bought the latest version of the Littermaid which is a LME9000 and it is better with a timer so the rake doesn't run during during a 9 hour duration but I still run into the rake getting stuck at various times and it also pushes unused litter into the receptacle.  I go through way more litter now which is frustrating but it does seem to have a stronger motor.
summary: Breaks too easily and motor is weak and noisy

First of all....they smell so rank that even tho my dog will eat them, I can hardly stand to open the package.  They don't have much, if any effect on calming him either, so overall I think it was a learning experience and a waste of $$.

reviewText:
I don't know for sure that it's this food (which I ordered two cases of, from Amazon). But they've been tested for parasites and come up negative, and otherwise seem fine. I stopped giving this to them a few days ago, but they're still having terrible diarrhea.
I had been buying this from a local store, and all seemed well, but the price here was (of course) better, so I ordered a lot. It's within date - I did check - but it didn't look right to me. The kittens didn't seem to mind, though, so I figured it must be OK. Now, thinking not. They've been sick since last Wednesday.
I'm still feeding them Wellness Kitten dry food, but I'm seriously considering taking them off that, as well. I'm at my wit's end, here; my poor kitties! :-(
Edit - 2/20/14. I've been slowly transitioning the kittens to Wysong. As of this morning, everyone is getting back to normal. It was DEFINITELY the Wellness kitten food, and I'm going to say it was both the wet AND dry that was causing the problem.
summary: Kittens have been sick ever since I fed this to them.

I thought the toothpaste would be great because the ingredients in them are probably as good as you can get for pet toothpaste.  I received the tube version and the toothpaste came out without any issues.  The toothpaste itself is a soft cream type consistency, not sticky or very runny.  It stayed on the toothbrush with no problem.  From a human standpoint, the smell was light and not too strong.  To me, it smells similar to bananas.  My dogs are used to toothbrushing from a very young age and have no problems opening their mouths and allowing me to brush them.  Unfortunately, all 4 of my dogs hated it.  Usually, they have little aversion to anything that resembles food, but, as soon as they took a sniff of it, each one closed their mouths and turned their head away.  As I said before, it smells similar to bananas, so, I thought my dogs would like it since they love bananas and eat them often.  I tried putting on even a smaller amount (less than pea size) and they still reacted the same way.  I really wanted to like the toothpaste, but, since all of my dogs hated it, I will have to throw this one out.

reviewText: Not impressed with these pads. They don't hold up well. The thickness is way less than other brands. The price was great, however the product wasn't thick enough to hold liquid.
summary: Not enough padding for these pet training pads

reviewText: Amazon should not allow sellers to list on their site without showing the ingredient.  They could be harmful for our pet's health.  For instance Sorbitol may increase the diarrhea.  As for coloring and flavoring?  Cats like meat, so why not make it fish flavored.  Ours loves tuna and especially white fish.  It is us humans that like fruit. Cats are carnivores  (meat eaters unless starved). There are always exceptions to this rule, but cats need the protein in meat  for good muscle health.  Dogs do not.

DEFINITELY not the same color as in the picture. I ordered the Extra Large size, and it is bright orange. The hide itself is nice and sturdy. My baby bearded dragon will be able to fit inside, but I don't think a full grown adult would fit.
Engineering part just isn't right.  Water will get in unless you do something else.  Use zip ties instead of hooks to attach or come off.

I bought this food because my cat has tummy issues, and someone's blog said this was the way to go. My cat wouldn't eat the food, however, so I am unable to say whether or not it would work. I tried everything, cutting it up, mashing it, mixing in food he likes. Oh well. I'm going to donate the rest to the shelter. I'm sure its great.

My Golden tore the felt material right off this during the first use. Normally Kong toy's are very durable but this one not so much. It looks like I can just remove the rest of the felt and still use it, will see how that goes.
Seat cover is to small/narrow and won't cover seat completely (medium size sedan). Initial quality impressions are good, however, it doesn't fully protect your seat and defeats it's purpose
summary: Good quality but too small to cover seat completely

reviewText: This Calming Liquid is not doing a thing, she is actually worse with this.

Either the treats are too big or they're too small. No matter what treat I use, they either get stuck or they fall out so easily that it defeats the purpose. I rarely use this or any other treat stuffing toy. i have also tried a variety of Kong toys. Although, the Kong toyd seem more durable than this, I don't really like either.
On a positive note, my dog is a really determined chewer and he hasn't managed to destroy this thing. He does get bored with it pretty quickly, though, so that could be why.

This toy looked so cute, I really hoped it was something that my two cats would like. Set up was pretty easy, it takes three AAA batteries, which are not included.  Attaching it to the counter was pretty easy, but don't use it on aa good table as it will leave a dent.

You press a button to turn it on and it alternately swings back and forth and occasionally swings over the top. Our older cat was very interested at first, until it swung over the top which scared her and after that she wouldn't even come near. Our younger cat, who I thought would love this, completely ignored it every time I tried to show it to her.

There's also a problem of the string getting tangled when it swings completely around. It tangled to the point it wouldn't work almost every time I turned it on.  Didn't work for us.

I wasn't too pleased with this product and we no longer use it. The bowls did not stay in their respective holders well at all. Additionally, it was not very spill proof and could easily be moved around or tipped over.

reviewText: MY greyhounds could not take this product as it made them sick , they refused to eat and were licking their stomach nearly all the time. I stopped the product after a short time.

summary: Sometimes the pieces are thick and sturdy, other times they're short and almost powdery

reviewText: dogs destroyed it immediately.

They both would eagerly take the treat from my hand then drop it after tasting, smell it as it lay on the ground, give it a lick or two, smell it again, then leave it there. My dogs usually eat everything they can so I was surprised. I guess the flavor was too bland or the taste was not good? They eat other treats and beg for more. They eat Blue Wilderness canned and dry grain-free food so I thought they would like these. I was disappointed because I liked the grain-free ingredients but I guess these treats aren't for us.

reviewText:
It is a bit noisy so that the noise distracts my cat and prefers to look at it instead of following the light.  My cat normally loves laser and unfortunately she prefers the hand held one that I control instead of this random one that goes so fast and doesn't seem to interest her as much.  The light isn't that bright and there's a button that can be slid up and down to direct where mirror supposed to angle.

I also have seen the Animal Planet laser interactive one that is similar and that one is brighter light, more difficult to change mirror angle, a bit quieter and pattern seems to make more sense, but neither product really interests my cat.  Unfortunately back to hand held lasers that occupy my time.  The only thing else I find that I can leave my cat to play by herself is to give her a Hexbug to follow around.

reviewText: NONE OF MY CATS WILL TOUCH OR EAT IT! TOSS IT IN THE TRASH......MONEY WASTE!
This is the noisiest pump I have ever had. I can hear it I in my upstairs bedroom (the fish tank is down stairs). I have it in a 30 gal tank just barely adequate would use it in any larger tank.

Worked good if I used it everyday for my dogs ear infection. But if I missed a day or two it would come back. I used the entire bottle. I also think it stung her. I now melt organic coconut oil and put it in her ears. It smells better, doesn't sting her, and it's safe for her to eat.

This was a great purchase at first, but as my puppy grew it was not durable enough to stand up to her. The included screws are very short and should be longer to withstand bigger dogs knocking the bell around.

Thanks!

I just received the large cage stand and have to agree with all of JS's points. In addition, one of the plastic feet in my box is completely squished and broken.  Also, the lower stand shelf is scratched and each of the two shelves are clearly different colors.  If I wasn't putting a cage on the top shelf the color discrepency would be a deal breaker.  As it is, I am on hold with the manufacturer hoping to get replacement parts.  Okay, off of phone after 20 minute hold.  According to Nora @ Hagen, I must fax the receipt with the broken parts listed on it to Hagen. reviewText:
It's not the worst thing in the world, after all, its made out of cheap molded plastic. But only two weeks, and the "foldable" grate which separates the fresh litter and the waste, already has a crack in it. The grate has unsecured itself from the supports on the bottom, so I have to hold it close in order to let the fresh waste return when tilting back. Though its great rolling the clumps of liquid waste into the removeable bin, its terrible at solid waste since it catches in places. You almost have to really roll it in order to catch everything, but you end up getting, un-spoiled liter into the trap. The tabs that seal the top from the bottom, do not secure neatly, again, I excuse its design due its material. However, the one side that doesn't have a tab and is supposed to be flush when you tilt the box, often leaks the fresh litter out since the tabs do a poor job at keeping the box together.

In the end, I just removed the top and now its just an overpriced, open litter box. Might consider getting something else...
summary: Great idea, but the cheap plastic makes this a bad product overall

I'm so bummed! Been using this product my dog's entire life. He just turned 4 in March 2016. I brushed even when he had his baby teeth. Unfortunately, his adult teeth are in terrible shape now and I brush him using this toothpaste religiously. I do notice a fresher breath after use and, no, the breath does not smell like poultry afterwards. It just doesn't stink as bad. I am very disappointed with all my effort and to find that his teeth are decaying anyways. I've tried different toothbrushes and that didn't help. I tried using a wash rag to gently massage his teeth, that didn't work. Dental chews upset his belly and he does not like raw food or raw bones. Now, I'm thinking about trying my old Sonicare on him. I know the Sonicare will clean the heck out of his teeth, I just don't know if it will scare him due to it sounding like the grooming clippers. Another odd thing is that my dog has gotten worse and worse about letting me brush. He used to be ok with it because I think he really did enjoy the taste, but now he abhors it! Makes me sad forcing him especially when it is looking like we will have to get a professional cleaning one day in the near future. I did not want to do that and have my dog knocked out and that's why I have been so religious about the brushing. I'm pretty upset that it was all for naught. I am going to attempt to make an all-natural homemade dog toothpaste. I already brush him with coconut oil on the days I don't use Sentry. The only other positive thing I could say about the toothpaste besides it freshening breath is that a tube does last long.

This is kind of like feeding cardboard dog food. By that I mean it bulks up and fills up your dog and then they think they ate a lot but not really. There is a little struggling when they go outside to do their business, and it is not cheap. So I simply give them some real cooked vegetables with their regular food and they are happier and healthier.  An interesting observation is that commercial dog foods make your dogs hyper. When they eat vegetables they are mellow and calm. Do you think people think their dogs are happier after eating commercial dog foods when they are all energetic and seemingly  'ready to go' ? If your kids were like this you would diagnose ADHD and medicate them. The dogs need meat thing is pure BS as any vet will tell you 90% of allergies in dogs are caused by meat.  Measure the dog food with a scoop and then cut 10% for the dieting. They will loose weight and you don"t have to change their food. You really don't need this stuff. Sorry, but it is what I learned trying it out over a couple of bags.
Doesn't seem to freeze with water very well which was why we bought it... puppy wasn't very interested either.

So when I first got this I thought it was perfect for my big fat cat (20lbs) but it is NOT. The height is good but it is way too small for big cats.  After a couple weeks she was missing the box entirely with #1. Had to get rid of it and run to the local store the husky girl box

I bought a box of this at Wal-Mart and was a bit impressed because it was not at all dusty and doesn't have any kind of smell to it.

But my two cats had a different story to tell.  Mostly because the room I kept the litter boxes in started smelling like cat pee.  It was horrible.  At first, I thought the cats hated the litter but I couldn't find any pee on the floor and they were regularly using the box.  Which, by the way, cleanup was pretty simple.  It clumped pretty well for me.  But the smell still was slowly taking over the house.  I have no idea what was up but even without any pee clumps in the litter box, the smell stayed.

I finally decided it was just the litter and when I changed to a different brand, the smell instantly went away.

In short, this litter definitely retains the smell from cat pee.  And then shares it with everyone else.

reviewText:
The product description quite clearly labels this product as 'cotton'. I've never seen any kind of cotton that melts when heated, but both cut ends of this lead are melted to prevent fraying. I'm willing to bet this is simple nylon. It feels that way, and looks that way, and I guess I should have guessed from the price that this was too good to be true.

If you want cotton, to protect your hands, give this a pass. It's fine as a cheap lead, but I would not try training a dog with it.

Yes, the scoop is big, and yes it's sturdy, but the angle of the handle is so steep relative to the shovel, that when you have to apply any pressure, you have to make your wrist do the work, rather than your whole arm as it is with most other scoops. This could be a great scoop if they lowered the angle a little and reduced the gap size.  I'm going to give this to someone else hoping they like it and will try the other metal scoop available here on Amazon...

I thought I had scored as I was able to pick it up with one hand - and one bag filled 2 litter boxes.  I was quickly disappointed.  It is essentially sawdust, and so dusty my allergies and asthma kicked in whenever I'd scoop.  It does clump but the clumps break apart and a good clumping litter isn't hard to find.  It tracks far and wide though, which is what I'd expect you get with light, tiny particles.  I tried this out because I ran out of the usual litter, Precious Cat, and saw this at the store.  I recommend staying away from this, especially if you and/or your cat(s) have allergies or asthma.  (I buy Precious Cat from at a pet store or from Amazon with free delivery of the heavy 40lb bag, and it's dust free, clumps the best out of any cat litter and we've tried 'em all with cats in the house for over 30 years).

reviewText:
Not recommended for a strong pulling dog.  I have a Bernese Mountain dog/English Mastiff.  First it stretched out and then the black piping started to come off and she was able to rip it almost all the way off. Then a large rip occurred right in the front center of the chest area straight down to the word Puppia. reviewText: The base is just adequate.  The problem is the water bottle/container.  Keep in mind that this is a four (4) gallon container.  At eight (8) pounds per gallon that is 32 pounds that will go from a upside to upright condition.  This is difficult even for someone reasonable strong.  The issue is the poor thickness of the jug.  It is just barely strong enough and I do not expect it to last with any endurance.  I filled the bottle and as I flipped it to upright I thought the bottle was going to collapse.  As the water filled the bottom container the just partially collapsed inward from the vacuum of the water displaced downward.  The bottle is just to thin for the volume  of the water.  Unless, like me, you have a lot of dogs  then I would recommend either another product or only fill the bottle half way.  If I had known I would have gladly paid a couple dollars more for a decent bottle thickness.  This is NOT the standard bottle, it is a very wide mouth with a holed cap.
summary: Very thin water bottle for 32 pounds of water

This is a nicely made harness, other than the sherpa slipping out from under my dog's armpits, as noted in other reviews of other sizes. That could be fixed with a few stitches. However, even without the sherpa (so the rope would be harsher against the tender armpit skin) this does NOTHING to reduce my dog's pulling. He is trained to walk on a slack leash next to me, but is dog reactive on leash and has pulled me over lunging at other dogs. He's an 85-pound Boxer and Ridgeback mix. I know to keep a safe distance and can focus him into a sit/stay if I see one coming, but sometimes one walks unexpectedly around a corner. That's why I got this harness, but it is totally ineffective, as is every other anti-pull harness I've tried. This one at least I have a little bit of control, unlike the ones that have the leash attachment in the front, but the ring for attaching the leash is at the end of the rope loop, so even walking him using my leash's handle which is next to the leash clip, I am still a foot farther away from him than on a regular collar - I use a martingale collar so he won't slip away. Oh well! I'll donate it to a rescue, its not a bad harness for a dog that doesn't pull.
summary: nicely made harness, does not reduce pulling

As far as odor control, forget about it! I had to change this every day which gets expensive with 3 rabbits! Two of them use a litter pan, but this is not good to use in the litter pan. The most suitable animals to use this bedding would be hamsters, gerbils, hedgehogs, and possibly a guinea pig (if they don't pee alot). This bedding was an excellent price, but did not work for what I needed.

Still held up we thought for about 2 days then only half of it held together...then it was gone. I mean it has never to this day been found. We have no idea where he shook it off. We hope he didn't eat it. He chewed it and another cat that we adopted at same time chewed it on him too. They say it's safe but plastic solids probably not..chemical maybe. Meantime we have a huge house no doubt. I suspect it's hiding in the back of my fabric walk in closet off sewing room but to date over 6 months later still no sign of it. I didn't even attempt to put the other one on a cat. What I did do was place it on a frequently used area and sleeping area the cats use. Not as effective. So overall I we won't buy anymore. felaway products did not work..sometimes they work for a few days to a few weeks but always these products seem to stop having a postive effect all to quick.

reviewText: They sniff it and walk away.  They won't even lick it.  I thought maybe they just weren't hungry so I waited until the next morning and let them wait 8 hours.  They were obviously hungry because they went nuts when they heard the can opener.  They rushed to their dishes of food, sniffed, and turned away. I loved that this product was entirely metal and truly chew-proof, and also that it could be folded up and stored away flat within the bottom tray.

HOWEVER, the product arrived broken, with no damage to the shipping box - the bottom tray was bent severely out of shape, the wire paint was chipped, and it couldn't lay flat.  Things happen, no big deal, so I ordered a replacement.  Amazon was wonderful and shipped one out immediately at no extra cost.  Unfortunately, the second cage was not only bent out of shape and chipped, but also rusted in a corner.  The clips that connect the wire to the base were bent and impossible to attach without an extreme amount of force.

IMPORTANT POINTS:
- BOTH the Amazon box and the product box were intact and not broken in any way both times I got the product.  Only the product itself was damaged, which tells me that this is not due to problems in the Amazon warehouse.
- The cage seems to be fairly sturdy and I could most likely fix everything with a wooden mallet and some pliers, but I am uncomfortable using a product that is already rusted and chipped inside its box.
- This cage is meant to be chew-proof because small animals like chewing things - if the paint is flaking off in the box, why would I assume my pet isn't going to chew off and eat the paint?

I returned this because I was not comfortable housing my pet in a cage that seemed to be of such poor quality for any period of time.  If you get one that is not damaged, then it seems like a great, practical, sturdy cage, but closely monitor the corners and the clips for chipped paint and rust which can be deadly to a small animal.

The picture is not entirely accurate: the cage door on the front is blue, not white, if that matters at all to you.
summary: Potentially good IF it isn't broken.  Watch out for paint chips and rust!

reviewText:
The 'bed' (piece of foam) actually measures 18 inches by 28 inches, so it is a bit small for the dog crate. Not sure if I'll keep it or send it back. Shame on Amazon for misrepresenting this item! Size does matter!!

FOLLOW UP: I contacted Customer Service and she said she would file a report to the warehouse and have them measure the item. It would take about five days. She then said I could exchange the bed for a new one, but there was no guarantee that it would be 20x30 as advertized! I consulted with the Dog, and she said "woof, woof", so we opted to keep the bed and Amazon took $5 off the price! But the description still says 20 inch by 30 inch and it is NOT.

August 31, 2013 Follow Up. Don't waste your money on this dog bed. I've had it about two months now and already the cover is falling apart and the foam retains the doggie odor. We are very disappointed with this product. Two paws down! Grrr....

This heater is every thing it's suppose to be.
I have the heater for two weeks for my freshwater aquarium of angelfish and discus.
The temperature marking on the side of the heater is accurate. You just need to let the heater stabilize which takes about a few hours depending on how much you want the temp to raise. I noticed that It heated up the water slowly maybe because it's made to not to shock the fishes. I raised the temp from 84 to 86 degrees. It heated my tank at a rate of about .5 degrees every 30 mins. And I have my tank in a cold room. The heater holds my tank temperature of 86 degrees constantly with a +/- .5 degrees in a avg room temp of 61 degree in a 25 gallon tank. I use a digital cooking thermometer to measure the temp and I check it every couple of hours.
The knob to adjust the temp is nice and big so it's easy to turn making it easy to adjust the temp in small increments.
(I had the Aquatop heater and the knob was thin which made it very hard to turn and adjust the temp.)
This heater is rated for 68 -93 degrees and I had it at the 86 degrees marking so I assume it can reach 93 degrees. The Aquatop heater is rated the same but I had to set it above the 89 degree marking just to reach 86 degrees. So it probably won't be able to get the water above 90 degrees. I had the same problem with the Aqueon Pro heater which is rated 68 - 88 degrees. I had it set for 86 degrees and the temp of my tank kept dropping from 86 to 84.5 degrees so I pulled out the heater when it dropped to 84.5 degrees. It's important to have a heater that can reach temp in the 90's for Ick, for certain meds and for treating your fishes w/o meds.
The heater is about 15" long from the top of the dial knob to the bottom of the heater with the glass tube about 12" long.
The only negative is the degree marking on the heater tube is hard to read.
Pros - holds temp constantly
- adjustment knob nice and big which makes it easy to turn
- accurate degree marking (but ALWAYS use a separate thermometer to check temp)
- can reach the temps it's rated for

Cons - hard to read degree marking

I had the Aquatop and Aqueon Pro and returned both of them. You can read my reviews on both of them.
So far this heater is working great and I only paid $14 with shipping
But only time will tell if it lasts.

**Revised review** 11/4/2013
Well the heater just died on me today. The light would not go on then I turned up the temp. I tested to see if the heater was working yesterday and it was. Then today I saw the temp at 72 degrees when it should have been at 80. Tried to turn up the temp but no light. Took it out of the aquarium and the tube was cold. The heater has died.
It worked well before it died. I rather it died than malfunction and overheat the aquarium. It only lasted from Feb to Nov., 9 months. 5 stars to 2 stars. 2 stars because it didn't malfunction and over heat the aquarium otherwise 1 star. How could it only last for 9 months, I still have a static heater from 30 years ago that is still good strong.
summary: So far working as it should - **revised review**

The tubing has zero support at the ends so there is no way for it to stand up.  Also it completely loses its shape after it's washed.

I got some double-wall cardboard and made rings for the beds, and got rid of the stuffing (that seems to be odor-absorbent, and not in a good way) and replaced those cushions with memory foam pillows.  Basically I took the shell and built a nice and practical bed out of it, hence the low 2-star score.

I wish I liked it. I am always looking for great cleaning products - especially for pet stains and urine. This didn't do the trick. Although I really disliked the smell (almost like a strong basil), I used it heavily. It didn't remove the color of the stains like other products I have used (Nature's Miracle). Unfortunately, because I couldn't handle the smell of it, I did not get down on the floor and smell it after to see if the urine smell was gone...I am not sure which I dislike more. Sorry....gotta pass on this one.

I received this product at a discounted price in exchange for my honest opinion. I count on reviews to be accurate for the items that I buy at full price just like everybody else does, so I rate products based on what I truly feel they deserve whether I received them at a discount or not. --
Updating:

Based on the comments by the manufacturer, i'm guessing this box would work better in a one-cat household. For the layering system to work in a multi-cat household, you'd have to be cleaning the litter box several times a day, and most people aren't going to spend their lunchbreak going home to scoop the poop.

reviewText: Kitten didn't take to these - not sure why

I posted earlier about the Love (grain-free beef) formula and now my dog is near finished this box of Embark.

I do think with some changes, The Honest Kitchen has the potential to be an excellent line of products. As with my thoughts on the Love grain-free beef formula, I feel the quality of the ingredients used can be improved. For example, use all organic plant products as the vegetation (potatoes, celery, spinach, apples) used in this formula are found on the Dirty Dozen list http://www.ewg.org/foodnews/list.php

My dog is eliminating massive piles of waste. We're talking two hand scoopers, and he is eliminating 5-6 times a day. I suspect it's from the large amounts of fibre in the food. Sure, fibre helps moves things along but a lot of fibre doesn't mean it's healthy. When he eats his raw food, he goes twice a day, maybe three times and his stool is much smaller. Now his BM's are like the size of a Great Dane's droppings. My dog actually had a disaster of an accident in the house. Just when I thought he was done eliminating for the day, I was wrong. I question how much of the nutrients he is actually absorbing.

A few things that leave me puzzled:

1) The product is Made in the U.S.A. and the company states they want to reduce their carbon footprint. However ingredients are sourced from across the globe. Why? We know the longer food travels, the less nutritious it is.
2) It annoys me when companies say they use "organic when possible". That simply means they're not committed to using organic ingredients. The U.S.A. has a thriving organic farming industry. Are organic fruits and vegetables not available to the company in the U.S.A.?
3) The use of filler ingredients like white potatoes, flaxseed.

Some positive notes about the food:

1) Dry formula is easier to store than raw.
2) Good to have on hand in case of emergency. Given that it's human grade, people can eat it too if they are in a dire situation.
3) My dog likes it (but his bowels don't).
I gave this product two stars for now because I'm not sure what the out will be so I'll give a update soon as I get the results.

reviewText:
I have two cats, a skinny 4-year old with inflammatory bowel disease and a chunky but healthy 2-year old. I originially got this hoping my sick cat would like the flavor and that he'd eat more, and that maybe he'd stop having such loose stools (he's on prednisolone and leukeran). He loved the flavor, but after devouring nearly a whole packet mixed with wet food he started looking nauseated and burping/hurking a little. I'm guessing that the "animal digest" ingredient has mixed proteins. He loves fish but absolutely cannot tolerate it in his diet as it makes him vomit. To be on the safe side I won't be giving this to him any more. With an otherwise healthy cat I might just decrease the initial dose, but with him it's not worth it.

The other cat, interestingly, would not eat the food I mixed the Fortiflora with. So I guess not all cats love the flavor. :)

For the IBD kitty, I'm going to go back to the capsules of probiotic I got from the vet (Vetri-Mega, I think it's called) along with the Fresh Digest enzyme blend I got at the pet store, both of which he's been consuming for a week with no obvious issues. To make food more appetizing, I have ordered powdered chicken liver from a cat breeder who also sells powdered mixes to supplement raw food diets. My sick cat appears to tolerate chicken, and many cats like the flavor of liver. The medications do seem to be helping his appetite, though.

Edit: Also, full disclosure, my IBD kitty passed away within a month of me posting the original review. It wasn't just IBD, it was cancer. :( The other cats are doing great, though.
summary: Undisclosed protein source too risky for IBD cats

***** update as of 4/26/2016 *****

Apparently Cashel has some production issues with the two largest full length mule masks. Warmblood and Draft. I have both the full length and regular length versions of both of these size masks. The long nose version has 13 inch ears. The regular version has 15.5 inch ears. They both should be 15.5 inches according to the sizing chart.

************************************
These are great masks, with the following exception: All of the mule/donkey masks are now made with 13" long ears. Well for a standard size donkey, that is fine. But for a Mammoth breed donkey (and probably large mules), that is way too short. 15" or longer is needed. The company must have made the two larger size masks (warmblood and draft) with 15" ears at one time and then decided to switch to 13" ones.

If it wasn't for the ear lengths, I would have given them 5 stars. Now I have to get my wife to take time and make longer ears for the larger masks.

They heard the comments and fixed this product. Now the ears are 15.5" long. Perfect!
summary: Still broken **** The ears are not long enough for the two larger sizes... bummer

reviewText: Recently got a cat and of course needed a carrier and was a bit disappointed in the description of this product.  Not only is it advertised as a large, but states that it can carry up to a 20 pound animal.  My cat recently weighed in at 10 pounds so there should be lots or room right? This carrier should have been advertised as medium at best.  Although the quality and construction look very good, size was very misleading. Can't recommend the product based on size.
Did not fit our 40 gallon tank but worked ok and cleaned up easy.

This is a neat little filter that sits outside of the tank and has a somewhat adjustable flow. It's quiet (barely there!) and cheap... what more could you ask for?

As it turns out, quite a bit. I bought this to go in my 5g tank with one betta, and within a minute of starting it up, he got a big tear in his tail fin, with the flow at its absolute lowest. Obviously, that's less than ideal.

The filter media it comes with is cheap; you get what you pay for. What I'm going to do, and what I suggest everyone does before using this filter, is pick up an Aquaclear sponge filter and biomax (the pellets in the baggie), put that in as your filter media, and use the filter pad it comes with to baffle the opening. That will result in better filtration and and a healthy cycle of good bacteria, as well as avoid those nasty tears in your betta's fins!

I'll try to update after more time has passed, but for now, I say this little filter is worth it as long as you accept that you won't be using it as is, right out of the box.
summary: Gets the job done, with some alterations.

reviewText: Let me start by saying that my dog loves these things.  The reason for the three star review is that when you do the math (3.5 oz for $17+) it comes to something around $80 a pound! USDA Prime Filet Mignon sells for about $24/lb.  So, for that money you would think that you might be getting freeze dried loin lamb chops, but no, the ingredients are "Lamb, Lamb liver and Lamb tripe".  Tripe is stomach lining, pretty much a by-product.  So, it's a good, high quality product with no additives, no grains, no junk you don't want to be giving your dog to eat.  My only issue is that the price is outrageous.  If money is no object, this is a great product.
summary: Three Times the Price of Prime Filet Mignon

reviewText:
Science Diet is becoming more and more reliant on cheap fillers for their non-prescription blends. I've seen their canned foods sinking so low as to include cellulose - wood fiber - as if that were acceptable. This dry food, fortunately, is free of wood cellulose, but full of other fillers rather than simply healthy, high quality ingredients.

This has two forms of corn, plus wheat and soy. The three most common allergens in dog food. Because of this, only two of my five dogs were able to try this food. Those two ate it mixed with their regular kibble, but they picked out the regular Avoderm kibble first and ate this last. When offered a bit of this stuff from my hand and a bit of the Avoderm from my other hand, they both ignored the Science Diet and chose the good stuff. Two star deduction for charging premium food prices for a mediocre filler filled food that my dogs don't like.
summary: Low end ingredients for a premium price. Contains corn, wheat and soy

reviewText:
I purchased the zion Ultrasonic Dog Bark Control Outdoor Pet Anti Bark Deterrent Stop Barking Device Bird House Box Design Waterproof for Home Garden Hanging Battery Operated with intent, and hope of encouraging my neighbor's extraordinarily yappy dogs to simmer down a whole lot. One of my dogs was scared of it, and the others didn't care. Unfortunately, it did not solve the issue I have with the neighbor dogs. Maybe it needs to be closer to them? Their yard is within the stated covered range, but maybe it would be better even closer.

I have extremely sensitive hearing, and could hear the high pitched squealing that the zion Ultrasonic Dog Bark Control Outdoor Pet Anti Bark Deterrent Stop Barking Device Bird House Box Design Waterproof for Home Garden Hanging Battery Operated made, and therefore wouldn't be able to have it inside my house near my front door to deter barking when the door bell rings, for example. If you don't have super duper bat hearing, you'd probably be okay, though.

As I type, the dogs are still barking next door. The moral of this story is to never move next to people, and move into the woods so that you can live in isolated peace.

Perhaps I'll look into purchasing a long range hose attachment to use as aqua deterrent from the yapping.

I was offered a discount for the zion Ultrasonic Dog Bark Control Outdoor Pet Anti Bark Deterrent Stop Barking Device Bird House Box Design Waterproof for Home Garden Hanging Battery Operated in exchange for my honest review, and I pinky swear I haven't compromised my integrity by changing my review based on the discount.
summary: Neighbor dogs still barking, however they might be robots sent to drive the neighborhood to drink

I used this litter for my guinea pig.  I put the litter bin in the corner of the cage and filled it with the litter.  In 2 hours time, I noticed my guinea pig was using it and I thought, "Wonderful! Now the cage bedding will last a few days longer!"  However, in a couple of days, I noticed each corner of the cage was being utilized for evacuation.  I normally clean the cage 1-2 times/week as there is only 1 guinea pig (Wilson) and was really hoping the litter box would allow me 1-2 times/every two weeks, of course with normal emptying of the litter box.  That is where the problem lies.  I went in 1 day later to empty the litter bin and noticed the pellets had become quite mushy; almost clay-like.  I gave the cage a thorough clean and bathed my little piggie and found his poor little paws were caked with the wet cement remnants of the pellets.  I had to soap and and soak his little claws and manually clean them out.  No wonder he stopped using the litter bin after 1 day.  I think it works to direct the guinea pig to evacuate in that spot, however, you will have to empty and replace everyday and that can get expensive...  I decided to finish the bag of litter and have chosen not to buy it again as the regular cage filler works fine in his litter bin and he prefers it as he has been using his litter bin 70% and the corners of his cage 30%.  If you are going to try this litter, you should change it at least once a day (depending on how much your little cavvy eats) because as soon as they empty their bladder, the pellets will turn to mush and it is not fun to clean that out. The eheim feeder itself is great. The station installed on my 36 gallon tank....caused a male dwarf gourami to decide that inside  and directly around the plastic box was his territory. Any fish that approached the platform and plastic box after food had dropped was rammed and chased by the dwarf gourami as a rule of thumb. This type of fish is occasionally territorial but generally peaceful and considered non-aggressive, so I imagine the possibility of the described scenario would be higher in tanks with aggressive or more territorial fish. The end result? One extremely bloated and fat dwarf gourami and a tank full of much thinner and more stressed fish.

I was cautious of overfeeding and having water quality issues as a noob to aquariums, so the cleanliness aspect of this feeding station appealed to me in the advertising. Admittedly, the clamp design for the platform is very well designed and the plastic box slides up and off easily- so the solution to my problem was to remove the box and simply leave the eheim automatic feeder on the remaining platform. Ultimately, fish looking for flake food on the surface do not seem to easily notice food sinking and drifting in a narrow vertical column under the feeding box, which is exactly what happens, because only one to two fish can fit in the box simultaneously to eat the food before it sinks.

 Having observed the process for a couple of weeks, my opinion is that this feeding station with it's small plastic box will encourage a few dominant fish to gorge themselves at the expense of the rest of the community, and I am skeptical of any benefits to the product as far as cleanliness/water quality.
