reviewText:
Here is a comparison of 5 types of bedding options I've tried for my guinea pig.

1) EZWhelp puppy pads - Trying to save money with this reusable option, but unfortunately the guinea pig's fur started turning yellow because it needs more "stuff" to brush up against his legs and absorb pee off them. The pads were very wet to the touch and leaking a little because the guinea pig peed so much. I suppose I could have put in some towels on top to add absorption, but by this time I was tired of having to clean hay from my washer and pet hair from my clothes. The guinea pig also would step on his poop and get it on his paws, so I had to be vigilant about removing the poop. I give these a 2 for messiness and not keeping my pet clean.
2) Aspen shavings - Cheapest bedding. Nice woody smell. Not very good absorption - I can see wetness on the bottom of the cage when I scoop it. Depending on the brand, you may need to watch out for sharp pieces of wood. I give these a 3.5 for lack of absorption but good odor control and price.
3) CritterCare - The little pieces feels hard like cardboard. They also get compacted easily and poop stays on top, which means the guinea pig steps on poop and frequently gets it stuck in his paws. Odor control isn't the greatests. However, it absorbs pretty well. And wetness shows up clearly allowing me to spot clean easily. I give these a 3 for absorption but poop on paws.
4) Carefresh - It is similar to CritterCare in wetness absorption and odor control. However, pieces seem softer, and it doesn't get as compacted than CritterCare although occasionally, poop still gets stuck on his paws. I don't like the blue bedding because it dyes his privates blue (not healthy). The white makes it hard to see and remove wet spots. Odor control is disappointing. I give these a 3.5 for absorption and texture but lack of odor control.
5) Kaytee - This is basically shredded tissue paper. At first, I was so excited because it looked and felt like soft, fluffy snow. It did keep the guinea pig's fur and paws cleaner. Unfortunately, this stuff gets very messy on your carpet when it's on its way to or away from the cage. The pieces are so thin and small and tend to fall all over the place. It also tends to clump together, making it difficult to separate the soiled spots from clean bedding. The white color makes it hard to see wet spots. Moreover, odor control and absorption are both disappointing. I can see liquid on the bottom of the cage under wet bedding. I give it a 2 for messiness and lack of absorption.

After all these tries, I decided to go back to Aspen because my husband is always complaining about odor. I'm planning to mix it with some Carefresh, as some people do, to improve absorption.
summary: Comparison of 5 bedding options for guinea pig

I have the elephant one.  Or rather, I HAD the elephant one.  I got it in a subscription box (forget which one, as I receive like 10 dog subscription boxes).  My dog thought it was awesome.  Now, she is not picky -- she thinks just about every toy is awesome.  So, this is more a review about how it held up.

For reference, my dog is an 83 pound Rottweiler.  She is super destructive.  Her main way of destroying toys is to hold down one part of the toy under her front paws/legs and pull up with her teeth on another part of the toy.  So there is one thing about the design of this toy that is great -- since it stretches, and it stretches quite a bit, she can't pull bits off by her usual method.  But she still tried to do so, so it kept her entertained.

After awhile, she started working on the elephant ears, and it wasn't too long (5 minutes, which is actually not bad for *my* dog) before she had a hole in one of them so I had to take it away.  She did not damage the body or the ball end.  She actually didn't deactivate the squeakers, either.

If I could change one thing about this toy (to increase my rating), I think I would just give it two ball ends with no ears/trunk/etc.  It is not as cute, but the appearance of dog toys is mostly to please humans -- the dogs don't care whether it is a purple elephant or a long blue tube.  I think it would last much longer without all the cute animal facial features.
summary: dog loved it, the stretchy part was a wonderful feature, but she destroyed part of the elephant head quickly

I have used this for several years on my carport, where the neighborhood cats try to mark their territory in the winter. It worked GREAT there on the hard surface.  This fall I was in the hospital for a time and one of my cats got a urinary track infection while I was there, and she peed on the carpet numerous times.  To my surprise, Nature's Miracle was just not up to getting rid of the smell.  I poured it directly on the carpet and let it soak in, left it a day, vacuumed it out with a wet vac and repeated the process a number of times.  It would seem to help, but as soon as the carpet dried, the cat urine odor was there again.  I finally had to rip out the carpet.  Whoo-ee, did the smell ever hit us in the face when we pulled it up. I guess that may indicate the Natures miracle never got down to all the cat pee, but I don't know what else I could've done. So, if the carpet is real thick, it may not work for you. Possibly pee smells different when they have UTI?
summary: Depends on where you use it

I found this product while looking for a bell to hang by the door for my dog. Ours is a sliding glass door with no knob, so this looked like a good option. After reading all the reviews for the Tell Bell and all the reviews for the Koolatron pet doorbell set, I realized I already had something that might work: the Staples Easy Button, which is available on Amazon for $9.98. It works basically the same way as the other products; it just says "that was easy" when my dog steps on it, is battery powered and does not require a transmitter/receiver. It also has 4 rubber feet on the bottom, which helps it stay in place on our tile floor. My 11 week old Airedale Terrier puppy, after a few minutes of "clicker training" (books, videos and clickers also available on Amazon) learned to use it today. Granted, that probably wasn't how the other products instruction manuals suggested training your dog, but it seems to have worked for us. Now to get him to figure out to only step on the button when he needs out to do his business, not just for fun and treats! I think he'll get it in no time. If you're really enterprising and would like to customize what the recording says, I also found a great web site that gives step-by-step instructions on how to record your own ("gotta go, gotta go," "Rover needs out," "Oo, oo, oo," or whatever). See [...]. If I hadn't already had one of these, I probably would have gone with the Tell Bell.

I bought the 42in half ramp for my 70lb Pit/Lab mix dog, Max. I have a Subaru Impreza Wagon. I have to wedge it into the bottom of back car seat with my foot to give it additional support. Don't use this ramp unless you are sure it will stay in place. If your dog falls off of it the first time, he/she will not use it again.

This is a sturdy, well-built ramp but it is awkward to store or use. It takes a lot of space in the back of our wagon, even when folded. I feel like I need to install adjustable aluminum legs on the sides of the ramp to help it with stability and rise of the ramp. Or I could install an attachment system to it so it will hold the ramp in place and won't tip over or fall off when the dog is on the ramp.

We stopped using the ramp for now. Max can go up and down from the back seat but he will need it someday. He's an older bull, 12 yrs old. I will probably make adjustments so we can use it again when the time comes.

Don't get me wrong---my dog loved this food, and I have read enough reviews to be satisfied that it's very good quality. I buy this cat food because the first two ingredients are chicken and turkey (instead of by-products or something else). The chicken and turkey, according to the manufacturer's website, are "hormone free and antibiotic free" and are "naturally preserved without the use of Ethoxyquin" ([...] Unfortunately the meat is not labeled organic and therefore the animals may have been fed crops treated with pesticides and other possible contaminants such as nitrates. After some web searching I found that there is BPA in these larger cans. The price for this is much cheaper than other canned foods of similar quality. At first my cats would not touch this food because they preferred Friskies. Once they realized that this was the only wet food they were getting they grew fond of it. They eat it somewhat slowly because it is not as addictive as other brands but this seems like a benefit to me. The texture is wet and unpleasant if you are using measuring cups but I feel it is worth it for the ingredients. My main complaints are that this food contains: ocean whitefish (which may contain mercury poison), ground brown rice (which may contain arsenic poison), carrageenan (a possible digestion and cancer-causing ingredient), and liver (cheap meat that may be toxic if cats eat too much). The price on this keeps changing so I may or may not continue to purchase it. Wellness is also a brand I've considered but their larger cans have BPA. I feed my cats dry food also to give them more variety and possibly lessen the effects of the bad wet food ingredients.
summary: Not the best ingredients but better than most and great for the price

Update 12/11/15: I finally found eye protection for my dog that is perfect (well, almost), The Rex Specs are my number one choice for dog eye protection from the sun. You can see my video review of them here: https://www.amazon.com/review/R3FYBWTCI1SXTA/ref=cm_cr_rdp_perm

Now back to my original review:

First off, my dog (85 lb German Shepherd) has pannus. The purpose of doggles is to protect his eyes from UV light so that he doesn't go blind. I could care less about the coolness factor, this review is strictly based on the ability to protect my dogs eyes from the sun, and his comfort in wearing them.

Second, I'm writing the same review for all the doggles, as a comparison, so you don't have to go looking through my other reviews to see how well the other types of doggles worked, or didn't work.

Third, I only make my dog wear them when it is sunny or overcast outside. I generally try to take him for walks/runs when it is either early morning/evening, or cloudy days. But he's full of energy, so I have to take him out on sunny days. This is when he wears doggles.

With the disclaimers aside:

1st choice:  Doggles Mesh Eyewear

I only recently tried these, and wish I had tried them sooner. I think what kept me from buying these is that in the photos, it appears as if your dog is not able to see through these, and because it only protects from 50 to to 60% of UV light. After spending ridiculous amounts of money in search for the perfect eye protection on every kind of doggle out there, this has become my first choice, though still far from perfect.

My dog can see very well with these, tolerates these the best out of all the other doggles. Will play with these on, and even chase a ball if other dogs are around chasing the same ball. I have noticed that sometimes he can't follow the toy as well, but that seems to be based on how fast the toy is flying and how high I throw it. So I still have to change how I play with him, but at least now he will play with eye protection on, which is huge.

The mesh is very light, which is why I think he doesn't mind it. It is kind of awkward looking as the mesh has pointy ends that cause it to stick out and not be laying directly on his eyes. I had my dog wear these for a full day once, and when coming back inside, I noticed he didn't rub his eyes against the couch as much as he does with other doggles.

The only reason I can't give this five stars is because it is only 50 to 60% uv protection rather than a 100% as offered with other doggles. This is a concern for me as the UV rays can really damage my dogs eyes due to the pannus. However, since my dog doesn't try to take these off anywhere near as much as the other doggles, I feel he gets a lot more protection from these since he actually keeps them on.

Since trying these, I have bumped down the ranking on the other doggles as noted below.

1st and 2nd choice: Doggles Large K9 Optix sunglasses, frameless

These are by no means perfect, and I fear the day they get broken. So far they have lasted several months with taking extreme good care of them. The reason they are one of my top choices is because they are 100% UV protection and my dog minds them the least (with the exception of the mesh doggles which are half the UV protection). I think what he hates about most doggles is that they have a bulky and heavy frame (from a dog's perspective), and they are not one lens, thus making them heavier on his head, and reducing his visibility. With these frameless doggles he does generally well, and is only intolerant of them when he's bored. He doesn't try to take these off as much, and as long as I have him distracted (going to a new place or chasing a critter), he doesn't mind them. He will more often than not play ball or catch a Frisbee with these on, but sometimes not. I wish I could give these five stars, but they are flimsy, and will fall apart eventually. I gave it four stars simply because they have held together thus far, with extra care. What really made this my top choice, is that they are frameless. I can see a huge difference in how my dog sees through these doggles in comparison to other doggles. So this gets first place simply for his comfort in vision. The straps fit nicely behind his ears and under his chin. If only they were made a little more sturdy...

I am making these both my first and second choice because the mesh eyewear only offers half of the UV protection that these do, and I can't use the mesh eyewear on really bright sunny days due to lack of the UV protection.

2nd choice: Doggles OriginalZ

The doggles originalZ only come with one color lens, which really isn't a big deal, but I have learned that even on overcast days, my dog needs eye protection, and he's less tolerant of these on overcast days versus on very sunny days. I think the darkness of the lens may reduce his visibility. He tries to paw his doggles off more so than with the frameless pair, but he minds these less than the ILS doggles. Overall, I'm happy with these because he does do fairly well with them when distracted, but I can tell he dislikes them. He usually will not chase a ball or Frisbee with these on, especially if there are other dogs around. I think he can't see the ball/Frisbee as well, and other dogs can, so he just gives up. Unless we're doing something new and exciting, he generally will find a shady spot, lay down, and watch the world play around him. It's sad to see him this way, but going blind will be worse for him, so I keep making him wear them. The doggles are well designed with the strap that goes behind his head and under his chin, which is easily adjustable, and vent holes on the sides of the doggles so that his eyes don't sweat/fog up.

3rd choice: Doggles ILS

I started out with the ILS doggles since they were the newest doggle out, and I liked the idea of the interchangeable lenses. I tried several colors of lenses, and found that my dog minds the brown lenses the least. It is nice to be able to remove the lenses that are scratched up and replace them with shiny new ones, and it's also nice to put in the clear lenses for overcast days when I want my dog to be able to see more, with the darkest lenses on really sunny days. So why not my favorite doggle? The dog hates them. The design is almost the same as the originalZ, with a few differences. The straps seem about the same as the originalZ, and the vent holes only differ in shape. The nose piece seems to be further apart than the originalZ, and even though the frame, when compared to the originalZ when not on, seems the same, they are a lot bulkier when on. I also found the foam that is between the doggles and the dogs eye is a little different, and seems to fall apart easier than the originalZ. The doggles company actually was kind enough to throw in some free foam with my latest order, but even super gluing it didn't seem to hold it well in place. Because the ILS doggles are much bulkier than the originalZ, and the dog hates bulky things on his face, he tries harder with these than any other doggles to get them off. Often, I find him running back to me with his doggles all distorted on his face with the straps all tangled. I have no idea how he manages, but it's sad to see him running back to me for help to fix his doggles, which I'm sure he's hoping I take off. No way would he even consider chasing a ball or catching a Frisbee with these on.

Last choice: Doggles K9 Optix Blue Rubber Gradient Frame with Smoke Lens Sunglasses

These are almost frameless, top of the frame is very thin, so my dog didn't seem to mind them as much, however, they broke within a week, even with very careful use, and constant watching of my dog so that he doesn't paw at them, and taking care to put them in a safe place when not in use. These were my favorite except for the fragility of them, until I found the frameless.

Okay, for those designers out there that want to make the perfect doggle, I hope you are reading this. You need a single lens doggle that is still very durable, sturdily built, and not too bulky. Basically, a single lens across both eyes, with a very light frame if any, such as the mesh with a softer plastic that is still 100% UV protection. Dogs are not human and do not see like humans, so why only create something that works for humans is beyond me. The frames in between the eyes are bothersome to the dog, and the bulk of most doggles (especially the ILS) causes discomfort. I actually bought a pair of ski goggles for humans and ended up sewing a chin strap to it to see if that would work, but it was too bulky and he was able to get them shook off by just shaking his head. But I could tell that his eyesight was just fine with the single lens.

Lastly, when back inside and we remove the doggles, my dog immediately runs to the couch and rubs his eyes against it, which we talked to the dog eye specialist about. It was suggested, that after wearing doggles, rather than let the dog rub his eyes against objects, that we put icepacks on his eye area. Just a little hint for those who have the same problem.
summary: I've tried every doggle out there, and I'm still looking for something that works

I typically use a martingale for walking.  She is not a dog that pulls unless excited by another dog.  I found the Halti to be ineffective for this.  Others using the Halti were using it for their dogs that were pulling excessively, along with the help of treats to keep the dog's focus.  I dislike using treats in this fashion, as I feel it keeps the dog's attention focused only on the treat, rather than the owner.  Would not use again, I'll stick to the standard martingale as it allows for better control.

(Summary at the bottom)
WARNING: DO NOT LEAVE THIS ON YOUR PET.

It leaves a soapy residue that will make your pet sick when he/she licks or chews on themselves (No, it will not prevent them from licking/chewing.)
Leaving it in your pet's fur will also not prevent the fleas from coming back.

However, this product does kind of work. Somewhat. It will not completely kill fleas on contact, although they clearly do not like it. If they are in contact with it long enough, they will die, but if they hop away immediately they'll survive with no problem. However, neither my nor my roommate's dog was comfortable with the smell. Their nose started running and they were sneezing, they were fine once we washed the spray off.

We also had better luck getting this flea spray to work when we used a flea comb at the same time. It'll make the spray sud/bubble up, so as you brush the fleas get caught in the bubbles and can't get away. Then rinse the dog off afterward and you're done. It works out really, really well for this, but does not work as a preventative spray (when going outside in areas known to have fleas) nor as a good bedding spray, since it leaves a residue that will sud up once it gets slightly wet (such as from wet feet after coming out of the shower)

Our dogs started hiding as soon as they see us with this spray bottle, we've diluted it with some extra water and the dogs are much more tolerant of it now. They still don't appear to like it very much though, the smell is far too strong for dog noses.

To summarize;

PROS:
- Kills fleas with direct, prolonged contact
- Works really well when paired with a flea comb
- Strong minty scent

CONS:
- Does not work as advertised
- Will not kill fleas on contact (the contact must be 5+ seconds minimum, if they hop away prior to that they will survive)
- Leaving the product in the pet's fur will make the pet sick (will not prevent the pet from chewing itself)
- Leaving the product in the pet's fur will NOT prevent fleas from returning (once it dries fleas don't seem to notice it)
- Spraying on carpets/bedding/etc does not work. It will make the fleas jump away initially, but they will return as soon as it dries.
- Smell is too strong for the animals, makes them sneeze + gives them a runny nose, they clearly dislike it.

Conclusion:
- It works IF you use it with a flea comb at the same time and immediately wash your pet off afterward
- Does not smell like strong chemicals (but the scent makes pets uncomfortable without watering it down)
- Does not work as a furniture or carpet spray
- Only worth the money if you are willing to use it with a comb and dilute the spray. (An upside is that diluting the spray will help you stretch it further, I'd suggest buying another spray bottle to help you do that though.)
summary: WARNING: Do not leave in your pet's fur! + Detailed review and summary

reviewText:
I've had this a couple months now, and the whole thing is falling apart and scratched. When it first arrived, it was relatively easy to put together and looked nice- an attractive way to hide an unattractive litter box.
The first week, I set a wicker laundry basket on top of it and just by pulling the basket off there were large scrapes on the top. So- I moved the cabinet out of the higher traffic area to avoid more accidental scratches that seemed to happen so easily.
Carrying this thing up the stairs was enough to loosen the joints and the table top popped off. A day or two later I scooted it over to vacuum and the top came off again, which caused the door and side paneling to fall over.
I felt like someone from those infomercials who can't quite figure out how to use a simple product without making a mess or having something break.

The good news is- for the first few days, it looked like real wood and was pleasant to look at. The door is easy to open and access the interior. A litter box sits in there nicely. Odors seem to be masked. No issues with cat accessing litter.

If you are planning on leaving this completely stationary and not setting anything remotely sharp or jagged on top, then this is a decent product to use as intended. I personally think for the price you deserve more.

Not sure if I should rate this three stars at all, but in fairness to Pet Zone, I am thinking that maybe it was just my pet. When I inserted the battery and turned this on, my cat was immediately interested. But that was about it. I think it's because it moves too fast and not sporadically enough (like one other reviewer stated, it's almost like being hypnotized in its spinning around and around and around). She sat and watched it for about 20 minutes, but then got bored and walked away. My dog was actually more interested in it than the cat, but both just watched. No one did anything to try to pounce or 'catch' the butterfly. I mean, it is cute and I was fascinated with it as well. However as a cat toy? Nah, didn't interest my feline.
summary: Not for my Lucy, but maybe for another cat

reviewText:
I am trying to get my cats, 5 and 11 years of age, eating more of a combo natural and/or raw diet. After reading many reviews, I decided to give this a try first to ease into it. Both my cats like beef flavored cat food and love real salmon, so I thought I would have the greatest chance of success with this beef & salmon flavor combination.

The idea is good, maybe not as expensive as pure raw,(though it is much more expensive than regular cat food bought in the grocery store) and is pretty easy to prepare since one only has to add some water. I followed the instructions for adding water - it only said to add one teaspoon per serving, but I didn't feel that was enough water. That amount of water did nothing and I wasn't able to mix the food enough. I did add a little more, but not much, and put it down for my cats.

Well, they both came over to their bowls to sniff it, but that was it. They just would not even try it. I even left it there for a while figuring that if they were hungry, they would try it, but no go. Neither one of my cats wanted anything to do with this food, so this is why I gave it 3 stars. I had a feeling my younger cat, age 5, wouldn't eat it since she doesn't like much of anything. She won't even touch raw meat, not even cooked meat or chicken. She will eat canned tuna & salmon, though. My older 11 yr old cat is very picky with cat food. He tends to like beef, tuna, salmon, and sometimes turkey flavors, but is very picky with brands. He might eat tuna in one brand, but not another. He does, though, LOVE raw and cooked meats. I have given him a tiny bit of raw hamburger meat that he's eaten. I've given him cooked chicken & cooked turkey, and he gobbles it up. He just will not touch this freeze dried food.
summary: Good Idea, But My Cats Don't Like It

reviewText: I rate this 3 stars vs. 4 stars for the Lamb flavor.  Beef for some reason does not rehydrate easily.  To get it even somewhat smooshable, I have to use warmer water than I'd like to which defeats the purpose of raw and probably kills whatever beneficial enzymes this food has.  Lamb wasn't quite as dense and broke up more easily. However, I am finding Stella & Chewy's patty shape to be much more conducive to efficient rehydration as there is more surface area to absorb the liquid. I'm bummed because Primal is a local N.Cal company that I'd like to support.  Wish they'd rethink their food shape from a brick to a flatter patty.
summary: Beef for some reason does not rehydrate easily. To get it even somewhat smooshable

reviewText: I think this would have been a great jacket for my little dachshund, but the size ordered was way too big.  Pawz, you must do a better job on your size chart. I do agility with my dog, but have a really small  yard. So I was excited to see this and thought it would be great to get for my tiny yard so we could practice at home.  The tunnel is good - short, but you can stake it down and it works great as a small or starter tunnel.  The weave poles are ok but they are short and bend easily with a medium to large size dog running through them.  The hoop is pretty much useless unless you have a very tiny dog and leave it on the ground.  It is too small and very flimsy.

The bottom line is the tunnel is nice, but the rest of the kit is kind of useless.  It might be good if you have a young child and a small dog that want to play, but otherwise you are better off building some equipment out of PVC pipe!
summary: A toy that isn't robust enough for real agility practice.

reviewText: Yes, leeches in an aquarium. Ugh. But this is supposed to kill them. According to the fish boards it is one of the only things that kills them. I treated once the first time and still saw another leech (a little one... one inch long) a couple of weeks later. Just re-treated two days in a row and have not seen one yet. By the way... this product has a chemical known the state of California to cause cancer. Don't use it unless you have to. It does also treat ich, but there are way better, safer products for treating ich, like Seachem ParaGuard 250ml.
summary: Has not yet gotten rid of leeches, and has a cancer-causing ingredient

reviewText: At first, I was looking for a brush that had soft little nubs on it, similar to a brush I would use on my own hair.  By mistake, I thought this brush had those types of nubs on it and was ready to send it back when it came, as it did not have them even though it was advertised as a "soft" slicker.  However, I decided to give it a try and was pleasantly surprised. Although at first glance this brush seemed no different from the other slicker brush I have (which my bichon doesn't like at all), she actually seems to like this brush much better, staying still for significantly longer than before until she decides she has had enough.  I gave the brush 4 stars and not 5 because she still doesn't really like being brushed and walks away when she sees this one.  But perhaps I should just give it 5 stars because maybe no matter how soft the brush is, she will never really like being brushed.  So 4-5 stars and thanks for a great product. =)

reviewText: All of my cats really liked this toy (they pretty much love anything attached to a string or wand), but unfortunately one of them was able to chew a piece of the material off on the tip and swallow it. She has asthma and spent the better part of a day wheezing, which I ended up taking her to the vet for because I thought something was seriously wrong (mind you, at that point in time I was completely unaware she swallowed anything she shouldnt have). Fast forward to that evening, I found a pile of throw up and sure enough there was a piece of this colorful fleece embedded in it. I think it aggravated her asthma, which was causing her to wheeze and have labored breathing.  Im sure there are a lot of toys out there that could be problematic, depending on how hard or aggressive your cat plays with it...but I just wasn't expecting her to want to eat this! And its not like my cat is set out to eat non-food objects or materials like this, but I guess it was just thin enough and too much like string, which pretty much most of my cats will try and chew on. I still give it a 4, because it does have a lot of entertainment factor, but this is just one of those toys that shouldnt be left unattended with your kitties!

My cat has been raised on Royal Canine after having a problem with our cats losing hair and throwing up my daughter and I started feeding our cats this formula of Royal Canine. My Sophie cat is four years old and my daughter two cats are 13 years old. Well, anyway they all did very well on it for the last three years now they changed the formula and my Sophie is throwing up again. So we go on the big hunt again for food. I am so sorry as she loves this food. I am sure it is the corn which is right up front in the ingredients which means it has a lot of corn. Cats can't digest corn. They need more protein. So I will be looking for a new food. Why do the companies keep changing the food well that is obvious as corn is a really cheap ingredient like soy. This is a real expensive food I think but did not mind paying for it as I believe we are what we eat and either spend it at the pet store or at the vets. Sophie has never been to the vet except for a rabies shot and but it really disappoints me that we have to find another food again.
summary: I won't be buying this again.

I was kind of on the fence about this, because of the mixed reviews. Eventually, I decided that the negative reviews seemed to be directed towards the smaller versions, and I knew that I didn't want to go smaller than three gallons for my dogs. We usually end up replacing a Petmate Le Bistro Waterer every two years or so, and I figured it was time for something a bit nicer. So far, this has fit the bill nicely. As others pointed out, the bottle cap wasn't perfectly threaded, however, it will "pop" when it's screwed in halfway, and it's fine from there. The little stopper in the cap actually works, so you can carry the water bottle from sink to dish without dumping water everywhere. Really, my only complaint is the design of the water bottle. It has a bit of an odd shape, and at 6'1" with proportionate hands, I still found it to be a bit awkward to hold and carry. Other than that though, the design is way better than the Le Bistro models I've used in the past. To be honest, the overall design is good enough that I think this may be the last waterer I'll need to buy. (Though at this price, I think I'd upgrade if they made a bottle that was easier to hold.)
summary: I must have lucked out with the 3-gallon.

I also wish the holder could unbuckle or unsnap the handle end, so that I could put  it in something like a drawer handle.

reviewText: Very well made. Very inexpensive. I had two rats that thoroughly enjoyed this in their old age. They definitely appreciated this hammock. It's a good size and very soft. You could definitely fit more than two rats in this hammock. It's also easy to clean. Just toss it in the washer then the dryer, and it's ready to be snuggled in again. I don't have a lot of pictures because I bought it while their health was declining and I prefer to remember the happier times. They chewed the straps up, an easy fix with safety pins, otherwise it's well made and will last a while. I would definitely buy this again if I ever have rats in the future.

It smells like high end cat food, & even close to gourmet people food.
All are cats gobble this up like nothing they've EVER had.

But = I have mixed feelings about the foods contents & price.
The Freskies canned food we feed our cats isn't the best out there, but it's more economical at $1.08 = per 13 oz can.
Having Friskies on hand, I compared it to Nutro which is $1.20 per 3 oz can.
(Fancy Feast $.57 per 3oz can)

Other than Friskies not smelling as close to people food, the contents are comparative.
And I was surprised to see Nutro contains even more Ash (hard on kidneys) than Friskies.
If it hadn't smelled so irresistible, I'd have given only 3 stars instead of 4.

>>> Nutro
Crude protein (min) = 12%
Crude fat (min) = 6%
Crude fiber (max) 1%
Moisture (max) = 78%
Ash (max) = 3.50%
Taurine = is listed in ingredients but doesn't give an amount.

>>> Friskies
Crude protein (min) = 10 %
Crude fat (min) = 5%
Crude fiber (max) = 1%
Moisture (max) = 78%
Ash (max) = 3%
Taurine (min) = 0.05

The 3 Nutro flavors are all called 'Chunky" = Salmon & Duck dinner / Chicken dinner / & Salmon & tuna dinner.
All three have the same consistency = soft mushy, nearly completely 'pate' with 6-8 very small chunks.
Photo = spread out Salmon & Duck dinner on 7" saucer & laid the 'chunky' pieces at the side.
(Friskies 'pate' isn't as soft and mushy)
Both have numerous vitamins added.

Because this food smells really good = I can see it useful for a sick cat when we can't get them to eat much of anything.
And for that purpose, I'd be grateful to buy an irresistible product.
Even the extra-small is too big for my 2.5 pound Chihuahua, but with some alterations of my own it works.  Hard to find anything small enough for a dog the size of mine.
very cute,cozy, keeps her warm, the size large was way to big. stick with the chart. my little one has it off in no time. I will alter it.

Update: "Sterling" demands play with this twice a day.  The challenge has been to avoid over-treating him. Here are the stages of utilization I have observed as he developed his understanding and techniques: 1) Initial confusion moved into using his LONG TONGUE to remove treats (a technique probably not available to smaller dogs) , which gradually transitioned into 2) ROLLING, which became 3) SNAP ROLLING.  As time passes, he now starts using the  4) LOW DROP, bouncing the treats out, moving into the 5) HIGH DROP,  and ultimately with the last, reluctant treats, he resorts to his 6) THROW DOWN.  It took a couple of weeks for him to learn these styles, but now he uses all of them as the situation dictates, and he continues to be very satisfied with the challenge provided.

I guess I should say my cat likes it.. not me :) .  After doing a lot of research, I found a dry food only diet is the worst thing for you cat.  Cats are carnivores and their food in the wild would be 70% water.  By nature they are not heavy water drinkers since theoretically they are getting their water from their food (mice, birds, whatever).  With that being said, any canned food is better than dry food since over time, a lot of cats on a dry food only diet will develop kidney problems.  I still leave a portion of dry out for my cat right before I go to bed, since he gets antsy if nothing is in his bowl.  Please do your research, a lot of times we don't know something is wrong with our cats until its too late since they tend to be stoic and hide their pain until they can't bear it any longer.
summary: Cat likes it, but I mainly feed wet food as its healthier for you cat!

reviewText: Kitties love 'em... especially at night. And yowl if they bat them someplace they can't reach them. I'm trying to get one of my cats to gain a little weight.  She normally eats a (more expensive) premium food most of the time, and I'm not planning on changing that, but I wanted to give her an extra meal each day.  This particular cat is highly partial to beef (doesn't care for chicken or even some kinds of fish) so I bought a couple of cans of this food to try it out.

First, the cat's assessment -- she practically inhales the food.  I feed her a half a can of this as a treat each day and it doesn't take her very long to eat, at all.  She gets excited when she sees me pick up cans off the counter.

Next, the texture.  To me, this food looks like chunks of some cat food "composite" and doesn't really look like "sliced" beef.  The pieces are a little bigger than other cat foods with this texture.  This food would not be appropriate for cats with dental problems, I think, but should work if your cat's teeth are healthy.

As for ingredients, this is definitely NOT a natural or premium food (which is why I'm not feeding it as a main food).  It does include wheat gluten, corn starch, soy flour, soy protein, and a few other plant-derived ingredients that probably don't belong in great quantities in a cat's diet.  There's also liver in this, pretty high on the ingredients list, so if your cat doesn't seem to like liver, you may want to stay away.  (Mine isn't that picky, as long as it's beef.)

This food should certainly never be fed to cats with inflammatory bowel disease.  However, for an otherwise healthy cat, this is a good treat or supplement.  Since my cat likes it so much, I'll give it a pretty high rating.
still working after almost 3 years two tumps up

My 2 cats are pretty picky, but they gobbled this stuff up. Both of them have sensitive stomachs, & I haven't seen this up on my couch or carpet yet, haha. It's very easy to mash up or cut up and it's not too stinky. My cats really enjoy the taste as well! Amazon has a great price too. I believe my local Costco has it for a little bit cheaper, but other than that, this is a great canned cat food for a great price on Amazon. Oh, I didn't give it a full 5-star even though I wanted to because I did notice that there is "so & so BY-PRODUCT" in the ingredients. I'm not 100% comfortable giving food like that to my pets so I sadly had to dock of a star.

A couple of interesting tips I'de like to give out about cat food is:

- Cats are carnivores. They need actual meat. Canned cat food comes closet to that. It's been proven that feeding cats wet food will improve their overall health & personality by a great deal. I have to admit that there has been less vomiting, healthy poops, & much more fun & interactive play time with each other & myself. I give half a cup of dry food with half a can of canned food to each cat everyday. [:

- A lot of people have misinterpreted that cats need to graze on food all day. This in fact isn't true at all. Cats are more closely related to their wild cousins; wild cats like lions, cheetahs, cougars, etc, don't eat everyday either because of an unlucky catch or other natural related things. The same theory applies to our domestic feline friends. Feeding cats once a day is plenty for them. Plus it keeps them in shape so they don't over eat!

(I read this in an old National Geographic. I'm also a graduate biological anthropologist).
Not to sure if its working or not.

reviewText:
First off, this is a LARGE dog door.  I know, I know ... the description clearly states that.  I was replacing a long-broken Staywell electronic dog door.  The actual flap opening on this door is about the same size as my old one, possibly a little bit smaller.  But, I had to significantly enlarge the hole in my door in order to install this door.

The door in question is a steel exterior door with styrofoam insulation.  The door's surface is not flat, as it has three decorative panels across the bottom (the top half has a large window).  After mounting the pet door onto the exterior door, I used a can of "Great Stuff" door & window expanding foam insulation to fill the gaps inside the pet door frame due to the recessed panels.  Once the expanding foam hardened, I used an Xacto knife to trim it even with the pet door frame and caulked around it inside and out.  It looks great now that it's done, and I'm confident that no moisture or air should penetrate around the door frame.

However, there is definitely a constant draft along the top of the flap, along the flap hinge.  Even when my dogs aren't near the door, meaning that it's locked, a draft can be felt coming through the hinge area.  When my dogs are near, and the door unlocks, there is a draft all around the door flap.  So, keep this in mind if you have a pet that likes to lounge right next to the door ... in cold weather, this will lead to significant energy loss.  As the weather gets very cold, I may just plan to use some 3M (or similar) plastic window insulating film and just let the dogs out.  I'll have to pay attention to our energy bill and how cold the hallway near this door gets as winter arrives.

Overall, the door is exactly what I expected.  I suspect that I would be happier with one of the much more expensive electronic doors (they open more like a power door window), but they are also a lot more expensive and wouldn't have fit my particular door.  If they would have fit my door, I might have considered spending the extra money ... over the long run, it may provide energy savings that make the extra cost worthwhile.
summary: Good pet door, may be drafty in cold weather

Well, my cat has only fallen off of this thing twice so far (she's not the most graceful of kitties), but she certainly seems to enjoy it!  I actually mounted mine on the side of my loft bed to give my furball a way to climb up and down between the bed and floor.  The reach of the climber is a tad short, but as it was designed for doors, and my loft bed is pretty tall, that's understandable.  I did what several other reviewers have shown in their photos, and bolted the climber directly into the "wall" of my loft with wood screws, using the longer bracket from the bottom of the product at the top of it instead, to make it a more even reach for my cat from the top or the bottom.

It did help to have two people present when putting the thing together, as it's a bit difficult to get the bolts to stay in place with the unit upside-down on the floor, while trying to tighten the things before they slip out of their holes.  If not for that, then I imagine I'd have gotten somewhat frustrated with the unusual assembly process.  Overall, it's pretty sturdy (especially after being screwed down), so my cat only has a bit of trouble climbing down from the higher platforms due to there not being very much ledge extending outward beneath the one she's on (the platforms are staggered, but not by much).  In any case, I think it's definitely worth the investment to make my small studio a bit more navigable and interesting for the fuzzy little doofus. :P
summary: Not bad at all, but a bit challenging to assemble and mount.

I began using this product for my feather-plucked parrots during their severe molt this year.  My Eclectus hens have not had feathers for many years (they were obtained in this very poor condition).  Diet made a huge difference, but it was not until I began the Vetri-DMG that feathering was kick-started and I could suddenly see many more blood feathers coming in.  Dispensed at the rate of 1 drop for 100 grams of body weight (2-4 drops on a tiny bit of bread) the product is readily accepted.  Long term benefits are not yet known; therefore, my star rating may change after product is in use over the next year.

reviewText: My cats (Persian, Exotic Shorthair and Domestic) all love the Royal Canin Foods (dry). We use the "Indoor Beauty" the "Persian" formula, and sometimes the Hairball formula. Also they have "Babycat" kibble for weaning Royal Canin Dry Cat Food, Babycat 34 Formula, 3.5-Pound Bag - tiny little 'crunchies' that are even smaller than the "Kitten Food". We adopted a 7-week-old kitten still getting replacement milk and I put a small bowl down just so she could get familiar with the smell of it. I planned to add water to it when we made the transition from replacement milk to canned food (perhaps) and then moistened Royal Canin Babycat. But within a few days she began eating it as is, without the water added. I was delighted that she took to it so quickly so that's in my shopping cart now. I gave it only 4 stars because there are a few new brands that have a higher "meat" content & less fillers, but my cats wouldn't eat any of them before or after I started them on Royal Canin. This one works for us. Amazon gets 5 stars for offering these foods at a reasonable price with free speedy delivery, allowing me to save both time and money. Good Deal!
summary: Several Good Formulas - something for everyone in fussy multi-cat households.

I wanted each of them to have their own brush so there would be no transference of yeast infection/skin infection between the two dogs.  The "bristles" are not really bristles, they are hard plastic so you have to be EXTREMELY gentle when your using it on their skin.  Once I got the pressure issue figured out the brushes worked well removing scales, dried up scabs (gross, huh?) and dry skin.  They are good for massaging medicated conditioner into the skin.  THE MOST IMPORTANT THING IS THAT YOU CANNOT SCRUB TOO HARD WITH THESE.  IT WILL HURT YOUR PET.
summary: Good scrub brush - just don't scrub too hard

reviewText:
My budgie absolutely loves this thing, it's the one toy that always has to be in his cage.  I call it his "budgie buddies," it becomes his safe place when stressed or just to hang out.  In fact, he loves this and other mirrors so much that I eventually decided he needed a real budgie buddy and got a second bird.  Now he spends less time with mirrors in general, but this is still a big favorite.

Other than the potential for single birds to get obsessed with their bird buddies, my one complaint is that this doesn't have a built-in perch.  Putting it at the end of a perch so that the perch is perpendicular to the mirror is not enough for my bird, he has to snuggle closely with his budgie buddies by holding on to the bottom edges.  It looks very uncomfortable, and he will sometimes spend the night like this.  I've found that by putting a small perch parallel to the mirror and very close that he will sit on that, but it's difficult to arrange.  I think it should have a small plastic perch for the bird to sit on like some other bird mirrors or food bowls.
summary: Budgie loves this, but no perch!

I bought an 8 piece set of these in the aqua color. They are relatively large stones about the size of a flattened golf ball. I tossed them into my aquarium hoping that they would be a nice accent against the black background and black sand at the botton of the tank. I let them charge for a few hours with the LED light bar in my aquarium and when I turned out the lights they sure did glow brightly. Also, they look cool under different colors of light. Some of the colors are dim enough (like red) that they still seem to glow. THis is my favorite thing about them. If you have a good adjustable light bar, these are great.

For the price (I paid 10) they are pretty good. I am giving four stars for two reasons. 1. The color is not distinguishable from the plain old alien green glow of nearly every glow in the dark item I have seen since I was a child. They were labeled "aqua" on the packaging, but even in full darkness (none of my lights being on) they appear green, not really blue or aqua at all. 2. Though they are themselves visible in the tank, they do not seem to cast any appreciable light of their own. Maybe I expected too much, but I thought that with a good charge they may illuminate their surroundings enough to see the fish swimming or light up the nearby plants. Of course I know it is unreasonable to think taht these would light up the tank like a light, but a little pool of mysterious light around each one didn't seem to be too much to ask.

Despite these two points, I find the stones (not stones, really, but plastic rock shaped objects) to be heavy, well-made and capable of giving off a little glow for several hours each night after I turn off my tank lights. I am not so sure that these would be my first choice for outdoor use, like to light a walkway, but they may glow for a while each night and mark the edge of a path or something. A great big pile, enough to fill a gravel walkway, would cost a fortune and likely dissappoint.
summary: Pretty cool for fishtank use! (I have aqua)

reviewText: Very durable for the price. Fits our crate perfectly. The waterproof cover is nice also.

I tried this carrier with my cat since plastic pet carriers can be heavy. Overall, I like it better than my hard plastic carrier, but it's too small to keep him in for any long period of time.

What I like about the carrier:
- Lighter than the hard plastic pet carriers.
- Cheaper than those hard plastic carriers too.
- A removable soft fleece comes with the carrier which you can attach via velcro to the bottom board (also removable).
- You can wash the fleece in your washing machine.
- Carrier has both a side opening for your pet as well as a top opening where you can drop them into the carrier.
- Quality construction, it will last a long time.

What I didn't like about it:
- There is a leash/clasp inside the carrier which dangles down. I assume that this is for clasping onto a dog's collar so he can't escape quickly. However, this clasp is VERY short and I worry it might choke a poor doggie attached to it. Additionally, if you're not going to use the clasp, there's no way to detach or stow it so it dangles around and bonks your poor pet with the metal clasp. Uncool.
- The carrier says it's for pets up to 22 lbs. However, as you can see in my photo of Peanut, a 12-lb cat, it's quite cramped for him. He can't stand up inside the carrier. I have no idea how it could hold a 22-lb dog without stuffing him in with a shoe-horn.
- It's difficult to get the cat into the carrier because the top opening is very narrow & you can bet that the cat's NOT going into the side opening voluntarily - no way, no how! It's probably okay for dogs who can walk into the side opening though.

The picture shows my 12-lb cat, Peanut, in the carrier at the vet. (Which explains his grumpy expression.)
summary: Excellent value for the price - but small

reviewText: I have two pugs.  Have been using this for years and my pugs seldom have any of that awful "pug breath" so many of that breed have. Since I have very hard water, I buy distilled water for them and add the Plaque Off to it.  I'm not sure that it truly makes a difference, but I figure it can't hurt.  (I see how the hard water clogs my shower head and kitchen sink nozzle...yuck.) My dogs get enough minerals from their food, so they don't need minerals from hard water.  My oldest pug is 11.  She does have some plaque, but my vet says it's a lot less than he typically sees in pugs, especially at her age.  I do notice that they seldom drink tap water while we are traveling and do prefer this mix.
summary: My vet sees less plaque than typical for pugs

Package arrived yesterday - be aware the box is huge. Much bigger than the cage box itself. I put it together last night, and the directions are mostly diagrams. If you are the one tasked to assemble the Christmas toys this shouldn't be a problem, minus the egg nog. The base is two main pieces and I like that the bottom tray clips off and you can remove the entire bottom of the tray for cleaning. Then the side walls go on with the vertical bars on the outside. Then the top snaps on. I like that the top has wire and it's mostly flat , so you can secure toys to the top of the cage.  Now the side walls do not fit together at the corners super tight as one would expect and plastic clips secure the corners together. I might be getting out the zip ties but for now we will try it out. There are also finger wide gaps at the top of the doors and this can't be helped. So if your budgie is an escape artist this might not be the home for you.
Pros:
First cage I have seen in forever that has all horizontal bars. This is super important for budgies since they climb a lot in their cages.
The removable tray that comes off the bottom easy.
Space! I got the large long model and it holds a coil rope swing and plenty of perches. I wanted deluxe accommodations for Angel.
Flat wire at the top to hang toys. I feel like we can use all the open space I this cage.
The food bowl covers are separate and removable.
The food bowls are divided and the support for the bowls is molded into the base. No tipping them over.
I like that the double door opens in or out.

Cons:
Gaps. This might be a problem for some birds.
The space between the floor and the first wire is pretty high. I put a short ladder there and I will see how Angel gets around. I removed the wire grate.
The cage came with brown perches that are smaller than the green vision perches I already had. I have to force the green ones between the cage wires.

I will come back and edit this later after Angel settles in.
Worked great on my dog and he has long hair
good value
Based on ingredients, this Taste of the Wild dog food is superior. However, our Rhodesian started to have hives after each feeding.  We switches dog food and the hives went away.
The latches are a little hard to work but it is cheap and exactly what I needed

Keeps the nasty droll that 2 German Shepherds create in one area. The mat is a little smaller than I had anticipated but does the job and does it well.

The grey color is nice. It blends in well and looks clean most of the time.
summary: Holds in water like it should.

My puppy will chew through anything & everything. We've tried several of the "other" sprays and they just wouldn't stop her. But this one does. I'm quite happy with it.

I feel a little silly writing a review for this but just in case it helps someone else . . . ordered three of these and they do the job.  It is a simple glass mercury driven thermometer with a green safety mark so it's easy to see if your temperature is in the safe range.  It is large enough to see without being obtrusive.  I used to have a large hang in the side tank that you couldn't miss . . . subtracted from the tank.  You can use the thermometer with or without the plastic suction cup.  The plastic from the suction cup quickly turned from a clear to a milky white.  Not sure why that happened, if it reacted to the warmth of the water or something in the water, but all three did it.  You do have to be careful to make sure the thermometer is high enough in the suction cup or it will pop off the side or pull out of the suction cup.  I found that out of the three I bought, two suction cups work fine, the other refuses to stay on the side regardless of where or in which tank I place it (I have both acrylic and glass tanks).  The thermometer does float in the tank, but the problem is it bobs around so you are never sure where it is, and it's hard to read temperatures without pulling it out (usual problem with mercury thermometers and how the line gets thin or thick depending on where you're viewing it from) so I don't see how you would realistically use this without a suction cup.  I feel like I should buy another one but also feel like even though this was a cheap purchase, it should have worked, and I don't like the idea of giving them more money for a defective unit.
summary: Nice but not perfect.  Possible quality issues

reviewText:
I got this because the cats always scratch on the door when we go outside.
One of my cats took to this immediately which was nice however it's not practical for a door that is constantly opened or closed because the scratcher gets caught in the way and is rather annoying.  I'll probably just set it on the floor with the other ones i have.  It's much narrower but the cats still took to it on the floor so for around $3 this wasn't a bad buy but it's not practical for my door.

I have 4 small dogs. I have bought the same treat in a different shape and they go crazy for them. I found these and did not realize they were not the same size since it is in the exact same box. It does not tell you on the ad that they are big. These things are huge and very thick. I could not even break it. I tried cutting it with a big knife and could not. I had to use something heavy to break it and then it shattered. I hope the big dogs are able to bite into it. The flavor is very yummie to them, though.

I have one male betta and he seems to like this food.  The food floats on top and doesn't sink to the bottom before he has a chance to grab the pellets.  I don't know how long this food stays fresh because it would last him at least a year, so I buy a new jar every other month or so.  His red color is vibrant and he's healthy.

These balls held up for a couple of weeks before they were completely destroyed.  I would use caution with a hard chewer but they held up better than I expected overall.  They are the size of a tennis ball and hollow with a squeaker which my dog loved.  He liked to chew them and unfortunately they fell apart after a couple of week so chewing.
birdie loves it and its her favorite thing and has fun pulling the strings.

I like the loops and odd shapes and so does my beagle puppy.  At 12 weeks, I fully expect her to destroy it, but so far, she isn't showing that much interest in it.  She'll watch it while I swing it for her and she'll go bring it back to me when I toss it for her.  It's a fetch toy for us.  It's nice and soft, so I may soak it with water and freeze it and she how it does.

It wasn't very expensive, from what I remember so if it ruins it, heck we had fun with it.  I just know that her teeth hurt like crazy, just like my son's did when he was a baby.  Anything cool is great.  These loops make it easy to grab.

This could be a life long toy for a tiny, toy sized dog.  I would recommend this for people like my mom, who has a "Morkie" (Maltese, and Yorkie mix) or other little dog.
summary: A bit small but great for tiny puppies/dogs

reviewText: I bought the 36-inch size.  It fits my 50-lb doodle just about perfect.  My 40-lb doodle also uses it, but if I had bought the next smaller size it should have been OK for her. I also have an 75-lb Lab who fits only from the shoulders down--her head hangs completely off the side--you'd think that would be uncomfortable for her but she seems to like it.  After just a couple of months usage, the center of the bed is almost flat but the edges are nice and fluffy so it has sort of a "bowl" shape that the dogs seem to just sink into.  I'm giving it only 4 stars because I think there should be at least SOME cushioning in the middle that doesn't go flat.  I'm thinking about cutting out a 36-inch circle of 2" memory foam and shoving it in there.

Frontline is great to use year-round for my three outdoor cats. As you might think, they are all extremely annoyed that I am putting some strange liquid on the backs of their necks, but no problem so far with skin irritation. Occasionally have to pick a tick or two off around their "tender" areas, but I also live in a heavily-wooded place. No sign of fleas as long as I apply the product consistently and on-time.

I hate there is a now a delay for this to ship due to the chemical components.

reviewText: LOVE LOVE LOVE! My dog is 80 points, skittish, and has a torn ACL. Getting her into my SUV is a nightmare. I've tried all kinds of products and methods. I finally had given up and decided I would just have to lift her every time. This product is simple, easily stored and pup friendly. It fits in the back of my car without taking up much space. It very easily folds out. That was my issue with products in the past. It took several minutes to get the product set up that it made it not worth it. Not the pet loader-it takes MAX of 10 seconds. It's light and easy. My dog is skittish so these products into the car typically don't work. But after about 5 minutes, even with her torn ACL, she was going up and down. It definitely is pricy, I got it as a gift because I kept going back and forth on the purchase. SO HAPPY with it.
summary: Best product out there, coming from someone who has tried them all.

I ordered 3 tags for my 3 dogs, each a different color. Each dog's name was written in large letters on one side and on the other side I asked them to put the name of my Town and State and both of my phone numbers ( home and cell).  When the tags arrived I noticed that the letters in the name of my town were so close together that it seemed to read: Comwell instead of Cornwall, because the "r" and the "n" were so close it looked like an "m". Not a BIG deal but when I contacted the seller about it, they were VERY gracious and offered to fix the problem right away. AND THEY DID!!! Very soon afterwards I received my new tags with the corrections made and the letters further apart and it looked fantastic. One does not often get such incredible service when you have a problem. Especially since this wasn't such a Huge problem and I could have lived with it, but I wanted it to be just right. I am VERY HAPPY with my tags and I urge anyone who wants a very nice tag for such a great price, to order from this company. You can't go wrong! Thanks so much, Providence Engraving!

When I first got the cage, I did have bedding/litter shavings covering the entire trays but learned very quickly that most of it wound up on the floor. Huge mess so I switched to the litter boxes. I also went to a hardware store and purchased a roll of wire mesh like u would have on a screen door and attached it to the sides and back of the cage to limit the amount of pellets and debris that fall out the sides. I also purchased storage bins to go on the shelf below the cage for easy access to their food and supplies.  I would highly recommend this cage to anyone that has 2 or more critters- my little guys love all the levels :)

reviewText:
Spark Prodigy LLC is one of those few companies that reaches out to the customer to make sure there aren't any problems. Unasked, they sent an informative, illustrated email explaining how the seat cover and anchors should be installed for optimum fit and efficiency and indicated their willingness to help if there are any problems.

The Pet Seat Cover is nicely finished and features durable, high quality materials.  Despite a daily onslaught of water and mud, courtesy of my wildly happy, usually wet Black Lab, the Seat Anchors hold the cover in place and my truck's back seat stays dry. I've vacuumed the cover but have not yet washed it.

Although I probably won't need it, the cover's limited lifetime warranty is a plus.  I am extremely happy with this product and will probably buy one for my daughter's truck.
summary: Excellent Product Backed by Outstanding Customer Service

reviewText:
Our Beagle has always had dry skin, and all of the "soothing oatmeal" dog shampoos weren't helping, at all. It also seemed like she only smelled nice and felt clean and shiny for a day or two after a bath. Like other shampoos were only covering the dry skin and "dog smell" instead of really cleaning it. I bathed her with this last week and she is still SO soft and shiny! She isn't scratching herself constantly anymore, and her skin seems way less flaky. I'm assuming that it's going to take a few more shampoos for the dandruff to totally go away and for her couple bald spots to grow back. I will try to update.

And she does NOT smell bad! She doesn't smell like perfume either, she just kind of has no smell at all, which is fine with me as long as it's helping her dry skin. I think if your dog stinks after using this, maybe you just didn't rinse them well enough. The soap itself does smell kind of funny, but my dog doesn't stink. Its a small bar but I rubbed it directly on her fur and have shampooed her twice and it's barely made a dent in the bar, so I think it should last a while.

Overall really happy with this and so relieved that she finally seems comfortable and clean and happy.
Wonderful bowls.  Perfect height for my senior pug.

Have used this for 2 of our dogs so far and the results are fun to see and help explain their personalities. One of the breeds detected was not a surprise but the rest? Complete surprise! Test was super easy to do and instructions were very clear. Kit comes complete with everything you need. Swab and mail, results in 2-3 weeks with complete, comprehensive details.

If my 3 cats didn't love this condo so I'd take a star or 2 off for the assembly of the ONLY piece you need to assemble. You have to screw the two pices of hard wood together with insufficiently weighted screws without guide holes. I suppose that there are no guideholes so that you can offset the top piece as you desire. Fine. You are going to need a proper power driver to do this job, And some real screws. Tryin to do this with a screwdriver or some little rechargable screwdriver aint gonna cut it at all. Trying to use a real power tool with the supplied screws may result in stripping or broke off heads (the screws not the cats). Ok, so you know that up front. I did not.

The other two are liable to jump straight to the top and again, the unit stays sturdy.  I got the blue one like in the picture; since none of my cats are blue they can't hide there.

They took to it instantly. The posts, the separate compartments - they knew it was for them and they love it. They look good in and on it.
summary: 5 STARS because the cats say so

reviewText: I ordered this product on the recommendation of my Veterinarian who specializes in dog behavior.  I noticed the quality of the product the first time I used it!  Not only does it get rid of the odor when used as directed, but at times it actually removed the stain. I went back to the carpet spot where I had applied the product and couldn't see the stain.  However, this is not a stain remover, just an odor remover. Bur I recommend this to anyone who has a pet who "accidentally" potties in the house.  I foster little rescue dogs and find this product to be the best one I have ever used! d

reviewText:
This pet door has paid for itself several times over in the 5 1/2 years since I've installed it.  Litter boxes are kept in a screened patio which stays whatever the outdoor temperature is.  With three cats, that's a lot of hot air coming in and cool air escaping.  This door solved that problem.  Heat stays out, cool air stays in.

The only thing I did differently when installing it was to insert some extra strips of foam insulation around the part of the pet door frame that is inside the door hole.  That invisibly sealed any small cracks where the door wasn't completely flush against the plastic pet door frame.

Medium size of this door works great for my 12-14 lb cats.  At first they were afraid to use it because the flaps are thicker than they're used to, and they had never encountered more than one flap in a door before.  Training them to go through the door took a few days:  Using coaxing, favorite treats on the other side, and some help holding the flap up (in the direction they'd normally push), they soon realized they could get through it themselves without any help.  Soon they were pushing through in both directions without any hesitation.
summary: Big AC savings in Florida heat. 3 cats + 5 years and it still works great.

I have ordered these when I was a young Buck as it where in aquarium life. My sister gave me a one gallon for a betta, then a 5 gallon for guppies. And then on my 18th birthday I got a 29 gallon! I was so thrilled and did silk plants, but none of my fish seemed happy. 2 years later I rescued a friends fish as she was going to heartlessly flush em to get some hamsters.. I wanted to make the tank PERFECT, So on my first paycheck in my first job ever. I ordered my own plants. And they came from Aquatic discounts. It was their Old 36 plant deal " No longer done from the looks of things"
But honestly, I was worried like everyone here . Some plants didn't have roots, But I did get a TON more then I ordered.  I came back here to find the order did say many would come as stems. Being a gardener. I know stems mean I could either graph em together into a bush. Or keep them separate and trigger root growth by cutting the first set of leaves and planting up to that point.

They where droopy for a few days, But soon after growth started. And years past, they grew bigger.. I'm not a fancy aquarium owner. I was a greenhorn. I had No special sub-strait, I don't believe in CO2 boosters. And the light was the same stuff that comes in those tetra aquarium kits at petsmart and stuff. And the growth was slow because of it. But the fish love em. And even now as I graduate them to a 55 gallon. I will still keep dwarf gourami and zebra plecos in my 29 gallon. Because the plants are deeply rooted in my tank. And outside of a water change now and then. It has been a completely self sustainable!

I have just recently bought the 50 plant deal. Knowing I'm more experienced in aquariums and plants. The first ones I obtained took a beating from me and my novice knowledge of Aquariums. But they fought back and now I don't have the heart to move them into the new tank, This is their home. and I'm happy to have them stay there and just get more X3.

All these posts about yellow "diseased" " Bad packaging" " not the amount I ordered" "no roots!"
It's so disappointing to see such a great business get attacked time and time again by noobies in the hobby. While I was literally winging it . No research, nothing outside of the gardening skills I learned growing up with a parent who loved landscaping. I'm No College student. Hell I work in a bakery and play video games for a living!

I give this review to the 35 plant kit, as the 36 is no longer available. but also because I don't remember if I did before..

Don't leave bad reviews because you don't know your tweezers from a grasper. Or Chicken poop from Coral powder. Or LED from Christmas lights. The list goes on. If a greenhorn in aquatics can make Every plant grow after shipment and a 7 day wait. As well as a Normal light bulb you'd find in a table lamp anda overstocked 29 gallon. The failure is not on Aquatics. It's on you.
summary: A Buyer of the past returns.

By far one of the best urine sprays out there. I've tried them all! No matter what it still smells like urine though! I scrub and scrub, I spray and soak, I repeat. Still smells.

Then came Natures Miracle Urine destroyer! Oh man, this stuff is great guys! If your dogs urinate on the floor, you'll want to try and soak up as much as you can with a cloth or paper towels. Then, you'll want to spray the urine destroyer all over the urine spot. Soak it good, then dry it as best you can, once again with a cloth or paper towels. Finally, spray again and let it sit until it air dries. That is how it's worked best for me!

My favorite part about this product is the sprayer that is attached! It works so nicely and sprays in a narrow stream, or a wide stream. Comes with batteries for the sprayer as well. This bottle lasted me at least 3 months guys, it's a ton of urine destroyer and it already comes with a sprayer attached so you don't really waste any. This is my second one now! Amazon makes it so easy for me to buy online and ships 2 days with Amazon Prime. Plus, you won't find this for a lower price in any store!
summary: The best urine spray for dogs!

I so wish I had one of these cooling beds when my beloved Eskimo Spitz was alive.  She used to lay on the air-conditioner floor vents to try and stay cool in the summer.  I think she would have loved this.

I filled it up with tap water from the kitchen sink and the filler material inside soaked up the water.  It is almost exactly the size of the average door mat.  If your dog can easily fit on that size, then this should work just fine.  One of our two dogs loves to lay outside in the sun and I worry about her over-heating.  It took a few tries to coax her to lay on the cooling bed but she finally got used to it.  Once she realized it was o.k. to lie on she would.

It rolls up nicely for storage or travel (has straps to secure it) and it's a lovely light blue color.  It seems very durable and I don't think even sharp toenails will pierce it.  I lay it with the stopper side down so my dog won't be tempted to chew on it.  It really does feel cool!  I sat on it and my backside was actually feeling cold.  I really like this and I hope it lasts for a long time.  I wish we had gotten it earlier this summer because it won't get used much longer for this season, but next summer it's getting a workout.
summary: I Love This Doggie Cooling Bed!!

I recently started fostering, and when my very first foster dog  a ginormous boxer mix  arrived with only a simple blue nylon collar, I hopped online and ordered a Puppia Soft Dog Harness in size XXL (black). Collars are easily slipped, and I wasn't at all comfortable walking him in it, even if just around our property.

Although I have five rescue dogs of my own, this is my first Puppia Soft Dog Harness; I thought that the soft mesh would be comfortable on his big frame, especially if he turned out to be a puller. The harness is well-made and seems solid and durable. The mesh is strong and the wide, generous design of the harness distributes force over a large area, making for a more comfortable fit, even when hes pulling me along at a swift jog.  (I exaggerate, but not by much.)

The harness slips on over the dogs head (as other reviewers have cautioned, this opening is NOT adjustable, so be sure to accurately measure your dogs head beforehand!) and you have to lift one leg up and into the shoulder opening to get it on. If your dog doesnt like having her paws handled, you might want to opt for a step-in design instead.

On the downside, the fabric collects stray fur like whoah, and dry leaves, grass, and burs can be difficult to pick off. Ive washed the harness several times now (hand wash in the sink, air dry) and, while dirt washes out easily, large bits of organic matter tends to stick.

Still, this harness is aces. I like it so much that Im thinking about upgrading some of the other dogs. (Save for Peedee, who really needs a no-pull design; and Mags and Finnick, who freak out when you handle their paws and like their step-in harnesses from Sassy Dog Wear just fine, thankyouverymuch.)

reviewText:
This bark collar really exceeded all of my expectations! We have a boxer puppy that just loves to bark and neighbors who don't love to hear it.  I really love that this gives out warning vibrations before it actually sends out a shock to the dog.  I was very specific on what I was looking for because I did not want something that would just shock the dog right away without giving it warning.

I know that it takes some time to train the dog what it means when the vibration goes off but ours caught on pretty quick! This collar allows the dog to still give out warning barks so you don't have to be afraid that if someone is approaching your yard or house that your dog won't be able to tell you.

You can change the intensity so it is custom to your dog.  It also comes with two different length contact points so it's very versatile to many different types of dogs.

The collar also is adjustable not only through the buckle but where you actually place the shock pack.  You just put it through the two holes and then screw on the contact points for whatever size you choose.

It came with an extra little blinking safety light you can hang from their collar.  It also has the testing piece to ensure that its working properly before putting it in your dog.  The testing piece also serves as a tool to tighten the contact points!

What I also really love about this bark collar is that it is waterproof, so no worries in the rain or bad weather, and its rechargeable so no more going through batteries left and right!!!

When you take it out of the box, charge it for a few hours before using it and the LED light will tell you when it's fully charged.  Make sure you read ALL instructions before using to ensure you are using it properly and safely.

I highly recommend this bark collar to anyone looking for a great quality, customizable, and easy to use collar!
